1.verse: In those days Mattathias, son of John, son of Simeon, a priest of the family of Joarib, left Jerusalem and settled in Modein.

2.verse: He had five sons: John, who was called Gaddi;

5.verse: Eleazar, who was called Avaran; and Jonathan, who was called Apphus.

6.verse: When he saw the sacrileges that were being committed in Judah and in Jerusalem,

7.verse: he said: "Woe is me! Why was I born to see the ruin of my people and the ruin of the holy city, and to sit idle while it is given into the hands of enemies, and the sanctuary into the hands of strangers?

8.verse: "Her temple has become like a man disgraced,

9.verse: her glorious ornaments have been carried off as spoils, Her infants have been murdered in her streets, her young men by the sword of the enemy.

10.verse: What nation has not taken its share of her realm, and laid its hand on her possessions?

11.verse: All her adornment has been taken away. From being free, she has become a slave.

12.verse: We see our sanctuary and our beauty and our glory laid waste, And the Gentiles have defiled them!

14.verse: Then Mattathias and his sons tore their garments, put on sackcloth, and mourned bitterly.

15.verse: The officers of the king in charge of enforcing the apostasy came to the city of Modein to organize the sacrifices.

16.verse: Many of Israel joined them, but Mattathias and his sons gathered in a group apart.

17.verse: Then the officers of the king addressed Mattathias: "You are a leader, an honorable and great man in this city, supported by sons and kinsmen.

18.verse: Come now, be the first to obey the king's command, as all the Gentiles and the men of Judah and those who are left in Jerusalem have done. Then you and your sons shall be numbered among the King's Friends, and shall be enriched with silver and gold and many gifts."

19.verse: But Mattathias answered in a loud voice: "Although all the Gentiles in the king's realm obey him, so that each forsakes the religion of his fathers and consents to the king's orders,

20.verse: yet I and my sons and my kinsmen will keep to the covenant of our fathers.

21.verse: God forbid that we should forsake the law and the commandments.

22.verse: We will not obey the words of the king nor depart from our religion in the slightest degree."

23.verse: As he finished saying these words, a certain Jew came forward in the sight of all to offer sacrifice on the altar in Modein according to the king's order.

24.verse: When Mattathias saw him, he was filled with zeal; his heart was moved and his just fury was aroused; he sprang forward and killed him upon the altar.

25.verse: At the same time, he also killed the messenger of the king who was forcing them to sacrifice, and he tore down the altar.

26.verse: Thus he showed his zeal for the law, just as Phinehas did with Zimri, son of Salu.

27.verse: Then Mattathias went through the city shouting, "Let everyone who is zealous for the law and who stands by the covenant follow after me!"

28.verse: Thereupon he fled to the mountains with his sons, leaving behind in the city all their possessions.

29.verse: Many who sought to live according to righteousness and religious custom went out into the desert to settle there,

30.verse: they and their sons, their wives and their cattle, because misfortunes pressed so hard on them.

31.verse: It was reported to the officers and soldiers of the king who were in the City of David, in Jerusalem, that certain men who had flouted the king's order had gone out to the hiding places in the desert.

32.verse: Many hurried out after them, and having caught up with them, camped opposite and prepared to attack them on the sabbath.

33.verse: "Enough of this!" the pursuers said to them. "Come out and obey the king's command, and your lives will be spared."

34.verse: But they replied, "We will not come out, nor will we obey the king's command to profane the sabbath."

35.verse: Then the enemy attacked them at once;

36.verse: but they did not retaliate; they neither threw stones, nor blocked up their own hiding places.

37.verse: They said, "Let us all die without reproach; heaven and earth are our witnesses that you destroy us unjustly."

38.verse: So the officers and soldiers attacked them on the sabbath, and they died with their wives, their children and their cattle, to the number of a thousand persons.

39.verse: When Mattathias and his friends heard of it, they mourned deeply for them.

40.verse: "If we all do as our kinsmen have done," they said to one another, "and do not fight against the Gentiles for our lives and our traditions, they will soon destroy us from the earth."

41.verse: On that day they came to this decision: "Let us fight against anyone who attacks us on the sabbath, so that we may not all die as our kinsmen died in the hiding places."

42.verse: Then they were joined by a group of Hasideans, valiant Israelites, all of them devout followers of the law.

43.verse: And all those who were fleeing from the disaster joined them and supported them.

44.verse: They gathered an army and struck down sinners in their anger and lawbreakers in their wrath, and the survivors fled to the Gentiles for safety.

45.verse: Mattathias and his friends went about and tore down the pagan altars;

46.verse: they also enforced circumcision for any uncircumcised boys whom they found in the territory of Israel.

47.verse: They put to flight the arrogant, and the work prospered in their hands.

48.verse: They saved the law from the hands of the Gentiles and of the kings and did not let the sinner triumph.

49.verse: When the time came for Mattathias to die, he said to his sons: "Arrogance and scorn have now grown strong; it is a time of disaster and violent anger.

50.verse: Therefore, my sons, be zealous for the law and give your lives for the covenant of our fathers.

51.verse: "Remember the deeds that our fathers did in their times, and you shall win great glory and an everlasting name.

52.verse: Was not Abraham found faithful in trial, and it was reputed to him as uprightness?

53.verse: Joseph, when in distress, kept the commandment, and he became master of Egypt.

54.verse: Phinehas our father, for his burning zeal, received the covenant of an everlasting priesthood.

55.verse: Joshua, for executing his commission, became a judge in Israel.

56.verse: Caleb, for bearing witness before the assembly, received an inheritance in the land.

57.verse: David, for his piety, received as a heritage a throne of everlasting royalty.

58.verse: Elijah, for his burning zeal for the law, was taken up to heaven.

59.verse: Hananiah, Azariah and Mishael, for their faith, were saved from the fire.

60.verse: Daniel, for his innocence, was delivered from the jaws of lions.

61.verse: And so, consider this from generation to generation, that none who hope in him shall fail in strength.

62.verse: Do not fear the words of a sinful man, for his glory ends in corruption and worms.

63.verse: Today he is exalted, and tomorrow he is not to be found, because he has returned to his dust, and his schemes have perished.

64.verse: Children! be courageous and strong in keeping the law, for by it you shall be glorified.

65.verse: "Here is your brother Simeon who I know is a wise man; listen to him always, and he will be a father to you.

66.verse: And Judas Maccabeus, a warrior from his youth, shall be the leader of your army and direct the war against the nations.

67.verse: You shall also gather about you all who observe the law, and you shall avenge the wrongs of your people.

68.verse: Pay back the Gentiles what they deserve, and observe the precepts of the law."

69.verse: Then he blessed them, and he was united with his fathers.

70.verse: He died in the year one hundred and forty-six, and was buried in the tombs of his fathers in Modein, and all Israel mourned him greatly.

annotations.1: [1] Modein: a village twenty miles northwest of Jerusalem.
annotations.2: [18] The King's Friends: a regular order of nobility at Hellenistic courts. The various grades are frequently mentioned in this book
annotations.4: [29] The desert: the sparsely inhabited mountain country southward from Jerusalem and west of the Dead Sea. It was an arid region with some perennial springs and a fair amount of rain in winter
annotations.5: [42] Hasideans: in Hebrew hasidim, "pious ones," a religious group devoted to the strict observance of the law. They were the forerunners of both the Pharisees and the Essenes. They first supported the Maccabean movement, but subsequently opposed it, regarding it as too political
annotations.6: [70] In the year one hundred and forty-six: 166 B.C

1.verse: In the year one hundred and seventy-two, King Demetrius assembled his army and marched into Media to obtain help so that he could fight Trypho.

2.verse: When Arsaces, king of Persia and Media, heard that Demetrius had invaded his territory, he sent one of his generals to take him alive.

3.verse: The general went forth and defeated the army of Demetrius; he captured him and brought him to Arsaces, who put him in prison.

4.verse: The land was at rest all the days of Simon, who sought the good of his nation. His people were delighted with his power and his magnificence throughout his reign.

5.verse: As his crowning glory he captured the port of Joppa and made it a gateway to the isles of the sea.

6.verse: He enlarged the borders of his nation and gained control of the country.

7.verse: He took many enemies prisoners of war and made himself master of Gazara, Beth-zur, and the citadel. He cleansed the citadel of its impurities; there was no one to withstand him.

8.verse: The people cultivated their land in peace; the land yielded its produce and the trees of the field their fruit.

9.verse: Old men sat in the squares, all talking about the good times, while the young men wore the glorious apparel of war.

10.verse: He supplied the cities with food and equipped them with means of defense, till his glorious name reached the ends of the earth.

11.verse: He brought peace to the land, and Israel was filled with happiness.

12.verse: Every man sat under his vine and his fig tree, with no one to disturb him.

13.verse: No one was left to attack them in their land; the kings in those days were crushed.

14.verse: He strengthened all the lowly among his people and was zealous for the law; he suppressed all the lawless and the wicked.

15.verse: He made the temple splendid and enriched its equipment.

16.verse: When people heard in Rome and even in Sparta that Jonathan had died, they were deeply grieved.

17.verse: But when the Romans heard that his brother Simon had been made high priest in his place and was master of the country and the cities,

18.verse: they sent him inscribed tablets of bronze to renew with him the friendship and alliance that they had established with his brothers Judas and Jonathan.

19.verse: These were read before the assembly in Jerusalem.

20.verse: This is a copy of the letter that the Spartans sent: "The rulers and the citizens of Sparta send greetings to Simon the high priest, the elders, the priests, and the rest of the Jewish people, our brothers.

21.verse: The envoys you sent to our people have informed us of your glory and fame, and we were happy that they came.

22.verse: In accordance with what they said we have recorded the following in the public decrees: Since Numenius, son of Antiochus, and Antipater, son of Jason, envoys of the Jews, have come to us to renew their friendship with us,

23.verse: the people have voted to receive the men with honor, and to deposit a copy of their words in the public archives, so that the people of Sparta may have a record of them. A copy of this decree has been made for Simon the high priest."

24.verse: After this, Simon sent Numenius to Rome with a great gold shield weighing a thousand minas, to confirm the alliance with the Romans.

25.verse: When the people heard of these things, they said, "How can we thank Simon and his sons?

26.verse: He and his brothers and his father's house have stood firm and repulsed Israel's enemies. They have thus preserved its liberty." So they made an inscription on bronze tablets, which they affixed to pillars on Mount Zion.

27.verse: The following is a copy of the inscription: "On the eighteenth day of Elul, in the year one hundred and seventy-two, that is, the third year under Simon the high priest in Asaramel,

28.verse: in a great assembly of priests, people, rulers of the nation, and elders of the country, the following proclamation was made:

29.verse: "'Since there have often been wars in our country, Simon, son of the priest Mattathias, descendant of Joarib, and his brothers have put themselves in danger and resisted the enemies of their nation, so that their sanctuary and law might be maintained, and they have thus brought great glory to their nation.

30.verse: After Jonathan had rallied his nation and become their high priest, he was gathered to his kinsmen.

31.verse: When the enemies of the Jews sought to invade and devastate their country and to lay hands on their temple,

32.verse: Simon rose up and fought for his nation, spending large sums of his own money to equip the men of his nation's armed forces and giving them their pay.

33.verse: He fortified the cities of Judea, especially the frontier city of Beth-zur, where he stationed a garrison of Jewish soldiers, and where previously the enemy's arms had been stored.

34.verse: He also fortified Joppa by the sea and Gazara on the border of Azotus, a place previously occupied by the enemy; these cities he resettled with Jews, and furnished them with all that was necessary for their restoration.

35.verse: When the Jewish people saw Simon's loyalty and the glory he planned to bring to his nation, they made him their leader and high priest because of all he had accomplished and the loyalty and justice he had shown his nation. In every way he sought to exalt his people.

36.verse: "'In his time and under his guidance they succeeded in driving the Gentiles out of their country, especially those in the City of David in Jerusalem, who had built for themselves a citadel from which they used to sally forth to defile the environs of the temple and inflict grave injury on its purity.

37.verse: In this citadel he stationed Jewish soldiers, and he strengthened its fortifications for the defense of the land and the city, while he also raised the wall of Jerusalem to a greater height.

38.verse: Consequently, King Demetrius confirmed him in the high priesthood,

39.verse: made him one of his Friends, and conferred the highest honors on him.

40.verse: He had indeed heard that the Romans had addressed the Jews as friends, allies, and brothers and that they had received Simon's envoys with honor.

41.verse: "'The Jewish people and their priest have, therefore, made the following decisions. Simon shall be their permanent leader and high priest until a true prophet arises.

42.verse: He shall act as governor general over them, and shall have charge of the temple, to make regulations concerning its functions and concerning the country, its weapons and strongholds,

43.verse: he shall be obeyed by all. All contracts made in the country shall be dated by his name. He shall have the right to wear royal purple and gold ornaments.

44.verse: It shall not be lawful for any of the people or priests to nullify any of these decisions, or to contradict the orders given by him, or to convene an assembly in the country without his consent, to be clothed in royal purple or wear an official gold brooch.

45.verse: Whoever acts otherwise or violates any of these prescriptions shall be liable to punishment.

46.verse: "'All the people approved of granting Simon the right to act in accord with these decisions,

47.verse: and Simon accepted and agreed to act as high priest, governor general, and ethnarch of the Jewish people and priests and to exercise supreme authority over all.'"

48.verse: It was decreed that this inscription should be engraved on bronze tablets, to be set up in a conspicuous place in the precincts of the temple,

49.verse: and that copies of it should be deposited in the treasury, where they would be available to Simon and his sons.

annotations.1: [1] The year one hundred and seventy-two: 141-140 B.C. The expedition began most probably in the spring of 140.
annotations.2: [2] Arsaces: Arsaces VI, also called Mithridates I, the Parthian king (171-138 B.C.). Parthians had overrun Persia and now held Babylonia, both of which had hitherto belonged to the Seleucid empire. The Greeks and Macedonians in these countries had appealed to Demetrius for help
annotations.3: [16] The embassy to Rome and Sparta was sent soon after Simon's accession to power, and the replies were received before Demetrius' expedition ( 1 Macc 14:1-3) - probably in 142 B.C
annotations.4: [27] Eighteenth day of Elul: September 13, 140 B.C. Asaramel: a Hebrew name meaning "court of the people of God."
annotations.5: [47] Ethnarch: a subaltern ruler over a racial group whose office needed confirmation by a higher authority within the empire

1.verse: Judas had heard of the reputation of the Romans. They were valiant fighters and acted amiably to all who took their side. They established a friendly alliance with all who applied to them.

2.verse: He was also told of their battles and the brave deeds that they had performed against the Gauls, conquering them and forcing them to pay tribute.

3.verse: They had gotten possession of the silver and gold mines in Spain,

4.verse: and by planning and persistence had conquered the whole country, although it was very remote from their own. They had crushed the kings who had come against them from the far corners of the earth and had inflicted on them severe defeat, and the rest paid tribute to them every year.

5.verse: Philip and Perseus, king of the Macedonians, and the others who opposed them in battle had been overwhelmed and subjugated.

6.verse: Antiochus the Great, king of Asia, who had fought against them with a hundred and twenty elephants and with cavalry and chariots and a very great army, had been defeated by them.

7.verse: They had taken him alive and obliged him and the kings who succeeded him to pay a heavy tribute, to give hostages and a section of

8.verse: Lycia, Mysia, and Lydia from among their best provinces. The Romans took these from him and gave them to King Eumenes.

9.verse: When the men of Greece had planned to come and destroy them,

10.verse: the Romans discovered it, and sent against the Greeks a single general who made war on them. Many were wounded and fell, and the Romans took their wives and children captive. They plundered them, took possession of their land, tore down their strongholds and reduced them to slavery even to this day.

11.verse: All the other kingdoms and islands that had ever opposed them they destroyed and enslaved;

12.verse: with their friends, however, and those who relied on them, they maintained friendship. They had conquered kings both far and near, and all who heard of their fame were afraid of them.

13.verse: In truth, those whom they desired to help to a kingdom became kings, and those whom they wished to depose they deposed; and they were greatly exalted.

14.verse: Yet with all this, none of them put on a crown or wore purple as a display of grandeur.

15.verse: They had made for themselves a senate house, and every day three hundred and twenty men took counsel, deliberating on all that concerned the people and their well-being.

16.verse: They entrusted their government to one man every year, to rule over their entire country, and they all obeyed that one, and there was no envy or jealousy among them.

17.verse: So Judas chose Eupolemus, son of John, son of Accos, and Jason, son of Eleazar, and sent them to Rome to establish an alliance of friendship with them.

18.verse: He did this to get rid of the yoke, for it was obvious that the kingdom of the Greeks was subjecting Israel to slavery.

19.verse: After making a very long journey to Rome, the envoys entered the senate and spoke as follows:

20.verse: "Judas, called Maccabeus, and his brothers, with the Jewish people, have sent us to you to make a peaceful alliance with you, and to enroll ourselves among your allies and friends."

22.verse: and this is a copy of the reply they inscribed on bronze tablets and sent to Jerusalem, to remain there with the Jews as a record of peace and alliance:

23.verse: "May it be well with the Romans and the Jewish nation at sea and on land forever; may sword and enemy be far from them.

24.verse: But if war is first made on Rome, or any of its allies in any of their dominions,

25.verse: the Jewish nation will help them wholeheartedly, as the occasion shall demand;

26.verse: and to those who wage war they shall not give nor provide grain, arms, money, or ships; this is Rome's decision. They shall fulfill their obligations without receiving any recompense.

27.verse: In the same way, if war is made first on the Jewish nation, the Romans will help them willingly, as the occasion shall demand,

28.verse: and to those who are attacking them there shall not be given grain, arms, money, or ships; this is Rome's decision. They shall fulfill their obligations without deception.

29.verse: On these terms the Romans have made an agreement with the Jewish people.

30.verse: But if both parties hereafter decide to add or take away anything, they shall do as they choose, and whatever they shall add or take away shall be valid.

31.verse: "Moreover, concerning the wrongs that King Demetrius has done to them, we have written to him thus: 'Why have you made your yoke heavy upon our friends and allies the Jews?

32.verse: If they complain about you again, we will do them justice and make war on you by land and sea.'"

annotations.1: [1] This chapter contains the account of the embassy which Judas sent to Rome, probably before the death of Nicanor, to conclude a treaty of alliance between Rome and the Jewish nation. Without precise chronology, the pertinent data are gathered into a unified theme
annotations.2: [1] The image of the Roman Republic greatly impressed the smaller Eastern peoples seeking support against their overlords ( 1 Macc 8:1-16), because of Roman success in war ( 1 Macc 8:2-11) and effective aid to their allies ( 1 Macc 8:12-13). Numerous interventions by Rome in the politics of the Near East bear witness to its power and prestige in the second century B.C. Cf 1 Macc 1:10; 7:2; 12:3; 15:15-24; 2 Macc 11:34. With the Roman control of Palestine in 63 B.C., the Republic and later the Empire became heartily detested. The eulogy of Rome in this chapter is one of the reasons why 1 Maccabees was not preserved by the Palestinian Jews of the century that followed.
annotations.3: [2] Gauls: probably the Celts of northern Italy and southern France, subdued by the Romans in 222 B.C., and again in 200-191 B.C.; but perhaps also those in Asia Minor (the Galatians), whom the Romans defeated in 189 B.C
annotations.4: [5] Phillip: Phillip V of Macedonia, defeated by a Graeco-Roman alliance at Cynoscephalae in 197 B.C. Perseus, his son, was defeated at Pydna in 168 B.C., and died a prisoner. With this, the kingdom of Macedonia came to an end
annotations.5: [6] Antiochus: Antiochus III, greatest of the Seleucid kings. He was defeated at Magnesia in 190 B.C. By the Treaty of Apamea in 189, he was obliged to pay Rome a crushing indemnity of 15, 000 talents. It was the weakening of Antiochene power and the growing military and economic influence of Rome that led Antiochus IV to adopt the policy of political, religious and cultural unification of Syria and Palestine
annotations.6: [8] Lycia, Mysia: regions in western Asia Minor. These names are restored here by conjectural emendation; the Greek text has "India, Media," most likely through scribal error. Eumenes: Eumenes II (197-158), king of Pergamum, an ally of Rome who benefited greatly from Antiochus' losses
annotations.7: [9-10] The revolt of the Achaean League, inserted here, occurred in 146 B.C., after Judas' time. It was crushed by the Roman consul Lucius Mummius and marked the end of Greek independence. The author regards all Greeks as the enemies of God
annotations.8: [16] They entrusted their government to one man: actually the Roman Republic always had two consuls as joint heads of the government. Presumably, a single one dealt with embassies and answered letters, hence the impression the Jews received; cf 1 Macc 8:15, 16
annotations.9: [22] The reply . . . on bronze tablets and sent to Jerusalem: The decree of the Senate would be inscribed on bronze and kept in the Roman Capitol, with only a copy in letter form sent to Jerusalem. The translation of the decree into Hebrew and then into Greek, as found here in 1 Macc, may have occasioned this error

1.verse: When Jonathan saw that the times favored him, he sent selected men to Rome to confirm and renew his friendship with the Romans.

2.verse: He also sent letters to Sparta and other places for the same purpose.

3.verse: After reaching Rome, the men entered the senate chamber and said, "The high priest Jonathan and the Jewish people have sent us to renew the earlier friendship and alliance between you and them."

4.verse: The Romans gave them letters addressed to the authorities in the various places, requesting them to provide the envoys with safe conduct to the land of Judah.

5.verse: This is a copy of the letter that Jonathan wrote to the Spartans:

6.verse: "Jonathan the high priest, the senate of the nation, the priests, and the rest of the Jewish people send greetings to their brothers the Spartans.

7.verse: Long ago a letter was sent to the high priest Onias from Arius, who then reigned over you, stating that you are our brothers, as the attached copy shows.

8.verse: Onias welcomed the envoy with honor and received the letter, which clearly referred to alliance and friendship.

9.verse: Though we have no need of these things, since we have for our encouragement the sacred books that are in our possession,

10.verse: we have ventured to send word to you for the renewal of brotherhood and friendship, so as not to become strangers to you altogether; a long time has passed since your mission to us.

11.verse: We, on our part, have never ceased to remember you in the sacrifices and prayers that we offer on our feasts and other appropriate days, as it is right and proper to remember brothers.

12.verse: We likewise rejoice in your renown.

13.verse: But many hardships and wars have beset us, and the kings around us have attacked us.

14.verse: We did not wish to be troublesome to you and to the rest of our allies and friends in these wars;

15.verse: with the help of Heaven for our support, we have been saved from our enemies, and they have been humbled.

16.verse: So we have chosen Numenius, son of Antiochus, and Antipater, son of Jason, and we have sent them to the Romans to renew our former friendship and alliance with them.

17.verse: We have also ordered them to come to you and greet you, and to deliver to you our letter about the renewal of our brotherhood.

18.verse: Therefore kindly send us an answer on this matter."

19.verse: This is a copy of the letter that was sent to Onias:

20.verse: "Arius, king of the Spartans, sends greetings to Onias the high priest.

21.verse: A document has been found stating that the Spartans and the Jews are brothers; both nations descended from Abraham.

22.verse: Now that we have learned this, kindly write to us about your welfare.

23.verse: We, on our part, are informing you that your cattle and your possessions are ours, and ours are yours. We have, therefore, given orders that you should be told of this."

24.verse: Jonathan heard that the generals of Demetrius had returned to attack him with a stronger army than before.

25.verse: He set out from Jerusalem and went into the country of Hamath to meet them, giving them no time to enter his province.

26.verse: The spies he had sent into their camp came back and reported that the enemy had made ready to attack the Jews that very night.

27.verse: Therefore, when the sun set, Jonathan ordered his men to be on guard and to remain armed, ready for combat, throughout the night. He also set outposts all around the camp.

28.verse: When the enemy heard that Jonathan and his men were ready for battle, their hearts sank with fear and dread. They lighted fires and then withdrew.

29.verse: But because Jonathan and his men were watching the lights burning, they did not know what had happened until morning.

30.verse: Then Jonathan pursued them, but he could not overtake them, for they had crossed the river Eleutherus.

31.verse: So Jonathan turned aside against the Arabs who are called Zabadeans, overwhelming and plundering them.

32.verse: Then he marched on to Damascus and traversed that whole region.

33.verse: Simon also set out and went as far as Ashkalon and its neighboring strongholds. He then turned to Joppa and occupied it,

34.verse: for he heard that its men had intended to hand over this stronghold to the supporters of Demetrius. He left a garrison there to guard it.

35.verse: When Jonathan returned, he assembled the elders of the people, and with them he made plans for building strongholds in Judea,

36.verse: for making the walls of Jerusalem still higher, and for erecting a high barrier between the citadel and the city, that would isolate the citadel and so prevent its garrison from commerce with the city.

37.verse: The people therefore worked together on building up the city, for part of the east wall above the ravine had collapsed. The quarter called Chaphenatha was also repaired.

38.verse: Simon likewise built up Adida in the Shephelah, and strengthened its fortifications by providing them with gates and bars.

39.verse: Trypho was determined to become king of Asia, assume the crown, and do away with King Antiochus.

40.verse: But he was afraid that Jonathan would not permit him, but would fight against him. Looking for a way to seize and kill him, he set out and reached Beth-shan.

41.verse: Jonathan marched out against him with forty thousand picked fighting men and came to Beth-shan.

42.verse: But when Trypho saw that Jonathan had arrived with a large army he was afraid to offer him violence.

43.verse: Instead, he received him with honor, introduced him to all his friends, and gave him presents. He also ordered his friends and soldiers to obey him as they would himself.

44.verse: Then he said to Jonathan: "Why have you put all your soldiers to so much trouble when we are not at war?

45.verse: Pick out a few men to stay with you, send the rest back home, and then come with me to Ptolemais. I will hand it over to you together with other strongholds and their garrisons, as well as the officials, then I will leave and go home. That is why I came here."

46.verse: Jonathan believed him and did as he said. He dismissed his troops, and they returned to the land of Judah.

47.verse: But he kept with him three thousand men, of whom he sent two thousand to Galilee while one thousand accompanied him.

48.verse: Then as soon as Jonathan had entered Ptolemais, the men of the city closed the gates and seized him; all who had entered with him, they killed with the sword.

49.verse: Trypho sent soldiers and cavalry to Galilee and the Great Plain to destroy all Jonathan's men.

50.verse: These, upon learning that Jonathan had been captured and his companions killed, encouraged one another and went out in compact body ready to fight.

51.verse: As their pursuers saw that they were ready to fight for their lives, they turned back.

52.verse: Thus all these men of Jonathan came safely into the land of Judah. They mourned over Jonathan and his men, and were in great fear, and all Israel fell into deep mourning.

53.verse: All the nations round about sought to destroy them. They said, "Now that they have no leader to help them, let us make war on them and wipe out their memory from among men."

annotations.1: [7] Onias: Onias I, high priest from 323-300 or 290 B.C. Arius: Arius I, king from 309 to 265 B.C. The letter was sent long ago, i.e., a century and a half before.
annotations.2: [9] The sacred books . . . in our possession: a reference to "the law, the prophets and other books," as mentioned in the Prologue to Sirach ( 1 Macc 12:1), after 132 B.C
annotations.3: [25] Country of Hamath: the Seleucid territory of Upper Syria northeast of Coelesyria and separated from it by the Eleutherus River. The latter territory was under the command of Jonathan ( 1 Macc 11:59, 60)

1.verse: When the Gentiles round about heard that the altar had been rebuilt and the sanctuary consecrated as before, they were very angry.

2.verse: So they decided to destroy the descendants of Jacob who were among them, and they began to massacre and persecute the people.

3.verse: Then Judas attacked the sons of Esau at Akrabattene in Idumea, because they were blockading Israel; he defeated them heavily, overcame and despoiled them.

4.verse: He also remembered the malice of the sons of Baean, who had become a snare and a stumbling block to the people by ambushing them along the roads.

5.verse: He forced them to take refuge in towers, which he besieged; he vowed their annihilation and burned down the towers along with all the persons in them.

6.verse: Then he crossed over to the Ammonites, where he found a strong army and a large body of people with Timothy as their leader.

7.verse: He fought many battles with them, routed them, and struck them down.

8.verse: After seizing Jazer and its villages, he returned to Judea.

9.verse: The Gentiles in Gilead assembled to attack and destroy the Israelites who were in their territory; these then fled to the stronghold of Dathema.

10.verse: They sent a letter to Judas and his brothers saying: "The Gentiles around us have combined against us to destroy us,

11.verse: and they are preparing to come and seize this stronghold to which we have fled. Timothy is the leader of their army.

12.verse: Come at once and rescue us from them, for many of us have fallen.

13.verse: All our kinsmen who were among the Tobiads have been killed; the Gentiles have carried away their wives and children and their goods, and they have slain there about a thousand men."

14.verse: While they were reading this letter, suddenly other messengers, in torn clothes, arrived from Galilee to deliver a similar message:

15.verse: that the inhabitants of Ptolemais, Tyre, and Sidon, and the whole of Gentile Galilee had joined forces to destroy them.

16.verse: When Judas and the people heard this, a great assembly convened to consider what they should do for their unfortunate kinsmen who were being attacked by enemies.

17.verse: Judas said to his brother Simon: "Choose men for yourself, and go, rescue your kinsmen in Galilee; I and my brother Jonathan will go to Gilead."

18.verse: In Judea he left Joseph, son of Zechariah, and Azariah, leader of the people, with the rest of the army to guard it.

19.verse: "Take charge of these people," he commanded them, "but do not fight against the Gentiles until we return."

20.verse: Three thousand men were allotted to Simon, to go into Galilee, and eight thousand men to Judas, for Gilead.

21.verse: Simon went into Galilee and fought many battles with the Gentiles. They were crushed before him,

22.verse: and he pursued them to the very gate of Ptolemais. About three thousand men of the Gentiles fell, and he gathered their spoils.

23.verse: He took with him the Jews who were in Galilee and in Arbatta, with their wives and children and all that they had, and brought them to Judea with great rejoicing.

24.verse: Judas Maccabeus and his brother Jonathan crossed the Jordan and marched for three days through the desert.

25.verse: There they met some Nabateans, who received them peacefully and told them all that had happened to the Jews in Gilead:

26.verse: "Many of them have been imprisoned in Bozrah, in Bosor near Alema, in Chaspho, Maked, and Carnaim" - all of these are large, fortified cities -

27.verse: "and some have been imprisoned in other cities of Gilead. Tomorrow their enemies plan to attack the strongholds and to seize and destroy all these people in one day."

28.verse: Thereupon Judas suddenly changed direction with his army, marched across the desert to Bozrah, and captured the city. He slaughtered all the male population, took all their possessions, and set fire to the city.

29.verse: He led his army from that place by night, and they marched toward the stronghold of Dathema.

30.verse: When morning came, they looked ahead and saw a countless multitude of people, with ladders and devices for capturing the stronghold, and beginning to attack the people within.

31.verse: When Judas perceived that the struggle had begun and that the noise of the battle was resounding to heaven with trumpet blasts and loud shouting,

32.verse: he said to the men of his army, "Fight for our kinsmen today."

33.verse: He came up behind them with three columns blowing their trumpets and shouting in prayer.

34.verse: When the army of Timothy realized that it was Maccabeus, they fell back before him, and he inflicted on them a crushing defeat. About eight thousand of their men fell that day.

35.verse: Then he turned toward Alema and attacked and captured it; he killed all the male population, plundered the place, and burned it down.

36.verse: From there he moved on and took Chaspho, Maked, Bosor, and the other cities of Gilead.

37.verse: After these events Timothy assembled another army and camped opposite Raphon, on the other side of the stream.

38.verse: Judas sent men to spy on the camp, and they reported to him: "All the Gentiles around us have rallied to him, making a very large force;

39.verse: they have also hired Arabs to help them, and have camped beyond the stream, ready to attack you." So Judas went forward to attack them.

40.verse: As Judas and his army were approaching the running stream, Timothy said to the officers of his army: "If he crosses over to us first, we shall not be able to resist him; he will certainly defeat us.

41.verse: But if he is afraid and camps on the other side of the river, we will cross over to him and defeat him."

42.verse: But when Judas reached the running stream, he stationed the officers of the people beside the stream and gave them this order: "Do not allow any man to pitch a tent; all must go into battle."

43.verse: He was the first to cross to the attack, with all the people behind him, and the Gentiles were crushed before them; they threw away their arms and fled to the temple enclosure at Carnaim.

44.verse: The Jews captured that city and burnt the enclosure with all who were in it. So Carnaim was subdued, and Judas met with no more resistance.

45.verse: Then he assembled all the Israelites, great and small, who were in Gilead, with their wives and children and their goods, a great crowd of people, to go into the land of Judah.

46.verse: When they reached Ephron, a large and strongly fortified city along the way, they found it impossible to encircle it on either the right or the left; they would have to march right through it.

47.verse: But the men in the city shut them out and blocked up the gates with stones.

48.verse: Then Judas sent them this peaceful message: "We wish to cross your territory in order to reach our own; no one will harm you; we will only march through." But they would not open to him.

49.verse: So Judas ordered a proclamation to be made in the camp that everyone make an attack from the place where he was.

50.verse: When the men of the army took up their positions, he assaulted the city all that day and night, and it was delivered to him.

51.verse: He slaughtered every male, razed and plundered the city, and passed through it over the slain.

52.verse: Then they crossed the Jordan to the great plain in front of Beth-shan;

53.verse: and Judas kept rounding up the stragglers and encouraging the people the whole way, until he reached the land of Judah.

54.verse: They ascended Mount Zion in joy and gladness and offered holocausts, because not one of them had fallen; they had returned in safety.

55.verse: During the time that Judas and Jonathan were in the land of Gilead, and Simon his brother was in Galilee opposite Ptolemais,

56.verse: Joseph, son of Zechariah, and Azariah, the leaders of the army, heard about the brave deeds and the fighting that they were doing.

57.verse: They said, "Let us also make a name for ourselves by going out and fighting against the Gentiles around us."

58.verse: They gave orders to the men of their army who were with them, and marched toward Jamnia.

59.verse: But Gorgias and his men came out of the city to meet them in battle.

60.verse: Joseph and Azariah were beaten, and were pursued to the frontiers of Judea, and about two thousand Israelites fell that day.

61.verse: It was a bad defeat for the people, because they had not obeyed Judas and his brothers, thinking that they would do brave deeds.

62.verse: But they did not belong to the family of those men to whom it was granted to achieve Israel's salvation.

63.verse: The valiant Judas and his brothers were greatly renowned in all Israel and among all the Gentiles, wherever their name was heard;

64.verse: and men gathered about them and praised them.

65.verse: Then Judas and his brothers went out and attacked the sons of Esau in the country toward the south; he took Hebron and its villages, and he destroyed its strongholds and burned the towers around it.

66.verse: He then set out for the land of the Philistines and passed through Marisa.

67.verse: At that time some priests fell in battle who had gone out rashly to fight in their desire to distinguish themselves.

68.verse: Judas then turned toward Azotus in the land of the Philistines. He destroyed their altars and burned the statues of their gods; and after plundering their cities he returned to the land of Judah.

annotations.1: [1] The events of this chapter occurred within the year 163 B.C.
annotations.2: Akrabattene: a district southwest of the Dead Sea
annotations.3: [4] Sons of Baean: 2 Macc 10:15-23 calls them simply Idumeans
annotations.4: [6-8] This summary anticipates the order of events and would fit better between 1 Macc 5:36 and 37. It corresponds to 2 Macc 12:17-23. The action was probably a reprisal for the massacre referred to in 1 Macc 5:13. Timothy was the Seleucid governor of Transjordan. Jazer: a town on the road from the Jordan to Amman
annotations.5: [15] Ptolemais: Hebrew Acco ( Judges 1:31), modern Acre, on the coast north of Haifa
annotations.6: [25] Nabateans: an Arab people who acquired wealth and power as caravan merchants in the final two centuries B.C. They settled down, established Petra as their capital, and for a time controlled all of Transjordan, even as far as Damascus. It was from a Nabatean governor that St. Paul escaped about 38 A.D. ( 2 Cor 11:32-33)
annotations.7: [46] Ephron: a city in Transjordan opposite Beth-shan, about five miles east of the Jordan River. Situated on a height, it dominated the valleys of the two tributaries of the Jordan

1.verse: John then went up from Gazara and told his father Simon what Cendebeus was doing.

2.verse: Simon called his two oldest sons, Judas and John, and said to them: "I and my brothers and my father's house have fought the battles of Israel from our youth until today, and many times we succeeded in saving Israel.

3.verse: I have now grown old, but you, by the mercy of Heaven, have come to man's estate. Take my place and my brother's, and go out and fight for our nation; and may the help of Heaven be with you!"

4.verse: John then mustered in the land twenty thousand warriors and horsemen. Setting out against Cendebeus, they spent the night at Modein,

5.verse: rose early, and marched into the plain. There, facing them, was an immense army of foot soldiers and horsemen, and between the two armies was a stream.

6.verse: John and his men took their position against the enemy. Seeing that his men were afraid to cross the stream, John crossed first. When his men saw this, they crossed over after him.

7.verse: Then he divided his infantry into two corps and put his cavalry between them, for the enemy's horsemen were very numerous.

8.verse: They blew the trumpets, and Cendebeus and his army were put to flight; many of them fell wounded, and the rest fled toward the stronghold.

9.verse: It was then that John's brother Judas fell wounded; but John pursued them until Cendebeus reached Kedron, which he had fortified.

10.verse: Some took refuge in the towers on the plain of Azotus, but John set fire to these, and about two thousand of the enemy perished. He then returned to Judea in peace.

11.verse: Ptolemy, son of Abubus, had been appointed governor of the plain of Jericho, and he had much silver and gold,

12.verse: being the son-in-law of the high priest.

13.verse: But he became ambitious and sought to get control of the country. So he made treacherous plans to do away with Simon and his sons.

14.verse: As Simon was inspecting the cities of the country and providing for their needs, he and his sons Mattathias and Judas went down to Jericho in the year one hundred and seventy-seven, in the eleventh month (that is, the month Shebat).

15.verse: The son of Abubus gave them a deceitful welcome in the little stronghold called Dok which he had built. While serving them a sumptuous banquet, he had his men hidden there.

16.verse: Then, when Simon and his sons had drunk freely, Ptolemy and his men sprang up, weapons in hand, rushed upon Simon in the banquet hall, and killed him, his two sons, and some of his servants.

17.verse: By this vicious act of treason he repaid good with evil.

18.verse: Then Ptolemy wrote an account of this and sent it to the king, asking that troops be sent to help him and that the country be turned over to him.

19.verse: He sent other men to Gazara to do away with John. To the army officers he sent letters inviting them to come to him so that he might present them with silver, gold, and gifts.

20.verse: He also sent others to seize Jerusalem and the mount of the temple.

21.verse: But someone ran ahead and brought word to John at Gazara that his father and his brothers had perished, and that Ptolemy had sent men to kill him also.

22.verse: On hearing this, John was utterly astounded. When the men came to kill him, he had them arrested and put to death, for he knew what they meant to do.

23.verse: Now the rest of the history of John, his wars and the brave deeds he performed, his rebuilding of the walls, and his other achievements -

24.verse: these things are recorded in the chronicle of his pontificate, from the time that he succeeded his father as high priest.

annotations.1: [14] In the year one hundred and seventy-seven, in the eleventh month: January-February, 134 B.C., by the temple calendar.
annotations.2: [15] Dok: a fortress built on a cliff three miles northwest of Jericho, near modern Ain Duq
annotations.3: [23-24] John Hyrcanus was ruler and high priest from 134 B.C. till his death in 104 B.C. These verses suggest that the book was written, or at least completed, only after he died

1.verse: Antiochus, son of King Demetrius, sent a letter from the islands of the sea to Simon, the priest and ethnarch of the Jews, and to all the nation,

2.verse: which read as follows: "King Antiochus sends greetings to Simon, the priest and ethnarch, and to the Jewish nation.

3.verse: Whereas certain villains have gained control of the kingdom of my ancestors, I intend to reclaim it, that I may restore it to its former state. I have recruited a large number of mercenary troops and equipped warships

4.verse: to make a landing in my country and take revenge on those who have ruined it and laid waste many cities in my realm.

5.verse: "Now, therefore, I confirm to you all the tax exemptions that the kings before me granted you and whatever other privileges they conferred on you.

6.verse: I authorize you to coin your own money, as legal tender in your country.

7.verse: Jerusalem and its temple shall be free. All the weapons you have prepared and all the strongholds you have built and now occupy shall remain in your possession.

8.verse: All debts, present or future, due to the royal treasury shall be canceled for you, now and for all time.

9.verse: When we recover our kingdom, we will greatly honor you and your nation and the temple, so that your glory will be manifest in all the earth."

10.verse: In the year one hundred and seventy-four Antiochus invaded the land of his ancestors, and all the troops rallied to him, so that few were left with Trypho.

11.verse: Pursued by Antiochus, Trypho fled to Dor, by the sea,

12.verse: realizing what a mass of troubles had come upon him now that his soldiers had deserted him.

13.verse: Antiochus encamped before Dor with a hundred and twenty thousand infantry and eight thousand horsemen.

14.verse: While he invested the city, his ships closed in along the coast, so that he blockaded it by land and sea and let no one go in or out.

15.verse: Meanwhile, Numenius and his companions left Rome with letters such as this addressed to various kings and countries:

16.verse: "Lucius, Consul of the Romans, sends greetings to King Ptolemy.

17.verse: Certain envoys of the Jews, our friends and allies, have come to us to renew their earlier alliance of friendship. They had been sent by Simon the high priest and the Jewish people,

18.verse: and they brought with them a gold shield worth a thousand minas.

19.verse: Therefore we have decided to write to various kings and countries, that they are not to harm them, or wage war against them or their cities or their country, and are not to assist those who fight against them.

20.verse: We have also decided to accept the shield from them.

21.verse: If, then, any troublemakers from their country take refuge with you, hand them over to Simon the high priest, so that he may punish them according to their law."

22.verse: The consul sent similar letters to Kings Demetrius, Attalus, Ariarthes and Arsaces;

23.verse: to all the countries - Sampsames, Sparta, Delos, Myndos, Sicyon, Caria, Samos, Pamphylia, Lycia, Halicarnassus, Rhodes, Phaselis, Cos, Side, Aradus, Gortyna, Cnidus, Cyprus, and Cyrene.

24.verse: A copy of the letter was also sent to Simon the high priest.

25.verse: When King Antiochus was encamped before Dor, he assaulted it continuously both with troops and with the siege machines he had made. He blockaded Trypho by preventing anyone from going in or out.

26.verse: Simon sent to Antiochus' support two thousand elite troops, together with gold and silver and much equipment.

27.verse: But he refused to accept the aid; in fact, he broke all the agreements he had previously made with Simon and became hostile toward him.

28.verse: He sent Athenobius, one of his Friends, to confer with Simon and say: "You are occupying Joppa and Gazara and the citadel of Jerusalem; these are cities of my kingdom.

29.verse: You have laid waste their territories, done great harm to the land, and taken possession of many districts in my realm.

30.verse: Therefore, give up the cities you have seized and the tribute money of the districts outside the territory of Judea of which you have taken possession;

31.verse: or instead, pay me five hundred talents of silver for the devastation you have caused and five hundred talents more for the tribute money of the cities. If you do not do this, we will come and make war on you."

32.verse: So Athenobius, the king's Friend, came to Jerusalem and on seeing the splendor of Simon's court, the gold and silver plate on the sideboard, and the rest of his rich display, he was amazed. When he gave him the king's message,

33.verse: Simon said to him in reply: "We have not seized any foreign land; what we took is not the property of others, but our ancestral heritage which for a time had been unjustly held by our enemies.

34.verse: Now that we have the opportunity, we are holding on to the heritage of our ancestors.

35.verse: As for Joppa and Gazara, which you demand, the men of these cities were doing great harm to our people and laying waste our country; however, we are willing to pay you a hundred talents for these cities."

36.verse: Athenobius made no reply, but returned to the king in anger. When he told him of Simon's words, of his splendor, and of all he had seen, the king fell into a violent rage.

37.verse: Trypho had gotten aboard a ship and escaped to Orthosia.

38.verse: Then the king appointed Cendebeus commander-in-chief of the seacoast, and gave him infantry and cavalry forces.

39.verse: He ordered him to move his troops against Judea and to fortify Kedron and strengthen its gates, so that he could launch attacks against the Jewish people. Meanwhile the king went in pursuit of Trypho.

40.verse: When Cendebeus came to Jamnia, he began to harass the people and to make incursions into Judea, where he took people captive or massacred them.

41.verse: As the king ordered, he fortified Kedron and stationed horsemen and infantry there, so that they could go out and patrol the roads of Judea.
