verses.1:
1 Maccabees
Introduction
The name Maccabee, probably meaning "hammer," is actually applied in the Books of Maccabees to only one man, Judas, third son of the priest Mattathias and first leader of the revolt against the Seleucid kings who persecuted the Jews ( 1 Macc 2:4, 66; 2 Macc 8:5, 16; 10:1, 16). Traditionally the name has come to be applied to the brothers of Judas, his supporters, and even to other Jewish heroes of the period, such as the seven brothers (2 Macc 7)
The two Books of Maccabees, placed last in the Douai version of the Old Testament, contain independent accounts of events in part identical which accompanied the attempted suppression of Judaism in Palestine in the second century B.C. The vigorous reaction to this attempt established for a time the religious and political independence of the Jews
1 Maccabees was written about 100 B.C., in Hebrew, but the original has not come down to us. Instead, we have an early, pre-Christian, Greek translation full of Hebrew idioms. The author, probably a Palestinian Jew, is unknown. He was familiar with the traditions and sacred books of his people and had access to much reliable information on their recent history (from 175 to 134 B.C.). He may well have played some part in it himself in his youth. His purpose in writing is to record the salvation of Israel which God worked through the family of Mattathias ( 1 Macc 5:62)-especially through his three sons, Judas, Jonathan, and Simon, and his grandson, John Hyrcanus. Implicitly the writer compares their virtues and their exploits with those of the ancient heroes, the Judges, Samuel, and David
There are seven poetic sections in the book which imitate the style of classical Hebrew poetry: four laments ( 1 Macc 1:25-28, 36-40; 2:8-13; 3:45), and three hymns of praise of "our fathers" ( 1 Macc 2:51-64), of Judas ( 1 Macc 3:3-9), and of Simon ( 1 Macc 14:4-15). The doctrine expressed in the book is the customary belief of Israel, without the new developments which appear in 2 Maccabees and Daniel. The people of Israel have been specially chosen by the one true God as his covenant-partner, and they alone are privileged to know him and worship him. He is their eternal benefactor and their unfailing source of help. The people, in turn, must be loyal to his exclusive worship and must observe exactly the precepts of the law he has given them
There is no doctrine of individual immortality except in the survival of one's name and fame, nor does the book express any messianic expectation, though messianic images are applied historically to "the days of Simon" ( 2 Macc 14:4-17). In true deuteronomic tradition, the author insists on fidelity to the law as the expression of Israel's love for God. The contest which he describes is a struggle, not simply between Jew and Gentile, but between those who would uphold the law and those, Jews or Gentiles, who would destroy it. His severest condemnation goes, not to the Seleucid politicians, but to the lawless apostates among his own people, adversaries of Judas and his brothers, who are models of faith and loyalty
1 Maccabees has importance also for the New Testament. Salvation is paralleled with Jewish national aspirations ( 1 Macc 4:46- 14:41), in contrast to the universal reign of God taught by Christ in the Gospel ( Matthew 13:47-50; 22:1-14). Also, destruction of the wall of the temple separating Jew from Gentile is an act of desecration in 1 Macc 9:54 but in Eph 2:14, an act of redemption and unification of both through Christ. On the other hand, association, in 1 Macc 2:52, of Abraham's offering up of Isaac (Gen 22) with his justification by God ( Genesis 15:6) is reflected in John 2:21, 22 just as the Scriptures are regarded as a source of consolation in 1 Macc 12:9 and in Romans 15:4
The Books of Maccabees, though regarded by Jews and Protestants as apocryphal, i.e., not inspired Scripture, because not contained in the Palestinian Canon or list of books drawn up at the end of the first century A.D., have nevertheless always been accepted by the Catholic Church as inspired, on the basis of apostolic tradition
1 Maccabees is divided as follows
I. Introduction: Hellenism in Asia Minor ( 1 Macc 1:1-9)
II. The Maccabean Revolt ( 1 Macc 1:10- 2:70)
III. Leadership of Judas Maccabeus ( 1 Macc 3:1- 9:22)
IV. Leadership of Jonathan ( 1 Macc 9:23-12:54)
V. Simon, High Priest and Ethnarch ( 1 Macc 13:1- 16:24

1.verse: When Demetrius heard that Nicanor and his army had fallen in battle, he again sent Bacchides and Alcimus into the land of Judah, along with the right wing of his army.

2.verse: They took the road to Galilee, and camping opposite the ascent at Arbela, they captured it and killed many people.

3.verse: In the first month of the year one hundred and fifty-two, they encamped against Jerusalem.

4.verse: Then they set out for Berea with twenty thousand men and two thousand cavalry.

5.verse: Judas, with three thousand picked men, had camped at Elasa.

6.verse: When his men saw the great number of the troops, they were very much afraid, and many slipped away from the camp, until only eight hundred men remained.

7.verse: As Judas saw that his army was melting away just when the battle was imminent, he was panic-stricken, because he had no time to gather them together.

8.verse: But in spite of his discouragement, he said to those who remained: "Let us go forward to meet our enemies; perhaps we can put up a good fight against them."

9.verse: They tried to dissuade him, saying: "We certainly cannot. Let us save our lives now, and come back with our kinsmen, and then fight against them. Now we are too few."

10.verse: But Judas said: "Far be it from me to do such a thing as to flee from them! If our time has come, let us die bravely for our kinsmen and not leave a stain upon our glory!"

11.verse: Then the army of Bacchides moved out of camp and took its position for combat. The cavalry were divided into two squadrons, and the slingers and the archers came on ahead of the army, and all the valiant men were in the front line.

12.verse: Bacchides was on the right wing. Flanked by the two squadrons, the phalanx attacked as they blew their trumpets. Those who were on Judas' side also blew their trumpets.

13.verse: The earth shook with the noise of the armies, and the battle raged from morning until evening.

14.verse: Seeing that Bacchides was on the right, with the main force of his army, Judas, with all the most stouthearted rallying to him,

15.verse: drove back the right wing and pursued them as far as the mountain slopes.

16.verse: But when the men on the left wing saw that the right wing was driven back, they turned and followed Judas and his men, taking them in the rear.

17.verse: The battle was fought desperately, and many on both sides fell wounded.

18.verse: Then Judas fell, and the rest fled.

19.verse: Jonathan and Simon took their brother Judas and buried him in the tomb of their fathers at Modein.

20.verse: All Israel bewailed him in great grief. They mourned for him many days, and they said,

21.verse: "How the mighty one has fallen, the savior of Israel!"

22.verse: The other acts of Judas, his battles, the brave deeds he performed, and his greatness have not been recorded; but they were very many.

23.verse: After the death of Judas, the transgressors of the law raised their heads in every part of Israel, and all kinds of evildoers appeared.

24.verse: In those days there was a very great famine, and the country deserted to them.

25.verse: Bacchides chose impious men and made them masters of the country.

26.verse: These sought out and hunted down the friends of Judas and brought them to Bacchides, who punished and derided them.

27.verse: There had not been such great distress in Israel since the time prophets ceased to appear among the people.

28.verse: Then all the friends of Judas came together and said to Jonathan:

29.verse: "Since your brother Judas died, there has been no one like him to oppose our enemies, Bacchides and those who are hostile to our nation.

30.verse: Now therefore we have chosen you today to be our ruler and leader in his place, and to fight our battle."

31.verse: From that moment Jonathan accepted the leadership, and took the place of Judas his brother.

32.verse: When Bacchides learned of it, he sought to kill him.

33.verse: But Jonathan and his brother Simon and all the men with him discovered this, and they fled to the desert of Tekoa and camped by the waters of the pool of Asphar.

35.verse: Jonathan sent his brother as leader of the convoy to ask permission of his friends, the Nabateans, to deposit with them their great quantity of baggage.

36.verse: But the sons of Jambri from Medaba made a raid and seized and carried off John and everything he had.

37.verse: After this, word was brought to Jonathan and his brother Simon: "The sons of Jambri are celebrating a great wedding, and with a large escort they are bringing the bride, the daughter of one of the great princes of Canaan, from Nadabath."

38.verse: Remembering the blood of John their brother, they went up and hid themselves under cover of the mountain.

39.verse: They watched, and suddenly saw a noisy crowd with baggage; the bridegroom and his friends and kinsmen had come out to meet the bride's party with tambourines and musicians and much equipment.

40.verse: The Jews rose up against them from their ambush and killed them. Many fell wounded, and after the survivors fled toward the mountain, all their spoils were taken.

41.verse: Thus the wedding was turned into mourning, and the sound of music into lamentation.

42.verse: Having taken their revenge for the blood of their brother, the Jews returned to the marshes of the Jordan.

43.verse: When Bacchides heard of it, he came on the sabbath to the banks of the Jordan with a large force.

44.verse: Then Jonathan said to his companions, "Let us get up now and fight for our lives, for today is not like yesterday and the day before.

45.verse: The battle is before us, and behind us are the waters of the Jordan on one side, marsh and thickets on the other, and there is no way of escape.

46.verse: Cry out now to Heaven for deliverance from our enemies."

47.verse: When they joined battle, Jonathan raised his arm to strike Bacchides, but Bacchides backed away from him.

48.verse: Jonathan and his men jumped into the Jordan and swam across to the other side, but the enemy did not pursue them across the Jordan.

49.verse: A thousand men on Bacchides' side fell that day.

50.verse: On returning to Jerusalem, Bacchides built strongholds in Judea: the Jericho fortress, as well as Emmaus, Beth-horon, Bethel, Timnath, Pharathon, and Tephon, with high walls and gates and bars.

51.verse: In each he put a garrison to oppose Israel.

52.verse: He fortified the city of Beth-zur, Gazara and the citadel, and put soldiers in them and stores of provisions.

53.verse: He took as hostages the sons of the leaders of the country and put them in custody in the citadel at Jerusalem.

54.verse: In the year one hundred and fifty-three, in the second month, Alcimus ordered the wall of the inner court of the sanctuary to be torn down, thus destroying the work of the prophets. But he only began to tear it down.

55.verse: Just at that time he had a stroke, and his work was interrupted; his mouth was closed and he was paralyzed, so that he could no longer utter a word to give orders concerning his house.

56.verse: Finally he died in great agony.

57.verse: Seeing that Alcimus was dead, Bacchides returned to the king, and the land of Judah was quiet for two years. Bacchides and Jonathan

58.verse: Then all the transgressors of the law held a council and said: "Jonathan and his companions are living in peace and security. Now then, let us have Bacchides return, and he will capture all of them in a single night."

59.verse: So they went and took counsel with him.

60.verse: When Bacchides was setting out with a large force, he sent letters secretly to all his allies in Judea, telling them to seize Jonathan and his companions. They were not able to do this, however, because their plot became known.

61.verse: In fact, Jonathan's men seized about fifty of the men of the country who were ringleaders in the mischief and put them to death.

62.verse: Then Jonathan and Simon and their companions withdrew to Bethbasi in the desert; they rebuilt and strengthened its fortifications that had been demolished.

63.verse: When Bacchides learned of this, he gathered together his whole force and sent word to those who were in Judea.

64.verse: He came and pitched his camp before Bethbasi, and constructing siege-machines, he fought against it for many days.

65.verse: Leaving his brother Simon in the city, Jonathan, accompanied by a small group of men, went out into the field.

66.verse: He struck down Odomera and his kinsmen and the sons of Phasiron in their encampment; these men had set out to go up to the siege with their forces.

67.verse: Simon and his men then sallied forth from the city and set fire to the machines.

68.verse: They fought against Bacchides, and he was beaten. This caused him great distress. Because the enterprise he had planned came to nought,

69.verse: he was angry with the lawless men who had advised him to invade the province. He killed many of them and resolved to return to his own country.

70.verse: Jonathan learned of this and sent ambassadors to make peace with him and to obtain the release of the prisoners.

71.verse: He agreed to do as Jonathan had asked. He swore an oath to him that he would never try to injure him for the rest of his life;

72.verse: and he released the prisoners he had previously taken from the land of Judah. He returned to his own country and never came into their territory again.

73.verse: Then the sword ceased in Israel. Jonathan settled in Michmash; he began to judge the people and he destroyed the impious in Israel.

annotations.1: [2] They took the road . . . Arbela, they captured it: This passage is restored, in part, by conjectural emendation. The present Greek text could be translated, "They took the road to Gilgal, and camping opposite Mesaloth at Arbela, they captured it." But Arbela (modern Khirbet Irbid) was in Galilee - on a high hill overlooking the western shore of the Sea of Galilee. Gilgal, on the contrary, was in the Jordan valley near Jericho. "Mesaloth" is probably a corrupt form of a Hebrew word meaning "steps, ascent."
annotations.2: [3] The first month of the year one hundred and fifty-two: April/May 160 B.C., by the temple calendar
annotations.3: [15] As far as the mountain slopes: conjectural emendation. The Greek text has "as far as Mount Azotus"; this is most unlikely. Apparently the Greek translator mistook the Hebrew word ashd't, "slopes," for a shd'd, "Azotus."
annotations.4: [33] Tekoa: home of the prophet Amos in the wild country above the Dead Sea, southeast of Jerusalem
annotations.5: [34] Omitted, it is a dittography of 1 Macc 9:43
annotations.6: [35] Jonathan sent his brother: this was John who was called Gaddi ( 1 Macc 2:2; cf 1 Macc 9:36, 38)
annotations.7: [36] Medaba: northeast of the Dead Sea
annotations.8: [45] Jonathan's force was apparently trapped in one of the many oxbows of the lower Jordan. Bacchides had crossed and caught them still on the east bank
annotations.9: [50] These sites constitute a ring on the edges of the province of Judea
annotations.10: [54] In the year . . . second month: May, 159 B.C
annotations.11: [62] Bethbasi: two miles east of Bethlehem and six miles north of Tekoa
annotations.12: [73] Began to judge: exercise the governing authority as in the book of Judges. With Jerusalem and the garrison towns ( 1 Macc 9:50) firmly in Seleucid hands, Jonathan's freedom of action was greatly restricted. Michmash, southeast of Bethel, famous for the exploit of the former Jonathan, son of Saul; cf 1 Sam 14

1.verse: As King Antiochus was traversing the inland provinces, he heard that in Persia there was a city called Elymais, famous for its wealth in silver and gold,

2.verse: and that its temple was very rich, containing gold helmets, breastplates, and weapons left there by Alexander, son of Philip, king of Macedon, the first king of the Greeks.

3.verse: He went therefore and tried to capture and pillage the city. But he could not do so, because his plan became known to the people of the city

4.verse: who rose up in battle against him. So he retreated and in great dismay withdrew from there to return to Babylon.

5.verse: While he was in Persia, a messenger brought him news that the armies sent into the land of Judah had been put to flight;

6.verse: that Lysias had gone at first with a strong army and been driven back by the Israelites; that they had grown strong by reason of the arms, men, and abundant possessions taken from the armies they had destroyed;

7.verse: that they had pulled down the Abomination which he had built upon the altar in Jerusalem; and that they had surrounded with high walls both the sanctuary, as it had been before, and his city of Beth-zur.

8.verse: When the king heard this news, he was struck with fear and very much shaken. Sick with grief because his designs had failed, he took to his bed.

9.verse: There he remained many days, overwhelmed with sorrow, for he knew he was going to die.

10.verse: So he called in all his Friends and said to them: "Sleep has departed from my eyes, for my heart is sinking with anxiety.

11.verse: I said to myself: 'Into what tribulation have I come, and in what floods of sorrow am I now!

12.verse: Yet I was kindly and beloved in my rule.' But I now recall the evils I did in Jerusalem, when I carried away all the vessels of gold and silver that were in it, and for no cause gave orders that the inhabitants of Judah be destroyed.

13.verse: I know that this is why these evils have overtaken me; and now I am dying, in bitter grief, in a foreign land."

14.verse: Then he summoned Philip, one of his Friends, and put him in charge of his whole kingdom.

15.verse: He gave him his crown, his robe, and his signet ring, so that he might guide the king's son Antiochus and bring him up to be king.

16.verse: King Antiochus died in Persia in the year one hundred and forty-nine.

17.verse: When Lysias learned that the king was dead, he set up the king's son Antiochus, whom he had reared as a child, to be king in his place; and he gave him the title Eupator.

18.verse: The men in the citadel were hemming in Israel around the sanctuary, continually trying to harm them and to strengthen the Gentiles.

19.verse: But Judas planned to destroy them, and called all the people together to besiege them.

20.verse: So in the year one hundred and fifty they assembled and stormed the citadel, for which purpose he constructed catapults and other devices.

21.verse: Some of the besieged escaped, joined by impious Israelites;

22.verse: they went to the king and said: "How long will you fail to do justice and avenge our kinsmen?

23.verse: We agreed to serve your father and to follow his orders and obey his edicts.

24.verse: And for this the sons of our people have become our enemies; they have put to death as many of us as they could find and have plundered our estates.

25.verse: They have acted aggressively not only against us, but throughout their whole territory.

26.verse: Look! They have now besieged the citadel in Jerusalem in order to capture it, and they have fortified the sanctuary and Beth-zur.

27.verse: Unless you quickly forestall them, they will do even worse things than these, and you will not be able to stop them."

28.verse: When the king heard this he was angry, and he called together all his Friends, the officers of his army, and the commanders of the cavalry.

29.verse: Mercenary forces also came to him from other kingdoms and from the islands of the seas.

30.verse: His army numbered a hundred thousand foot-soldiers, twenty thousand cavalry, and thirty-two elephants trained for war.

31.verse: They passed through Idumea and camped before Beth-zur. For many days they attacked it; they constructed siege-devices, but the besieged made a sortie and burned these, and they fought bravely.

32.verse: Then Judas marched away from the citadel and moved his camp to Beth-zechariah, on the way to the king's camp.

33.verse: The king, rising before dawn, moved his force hastily along the road to Beth-zechariah; and the armies prepared for battle, while the trumpets sounded.

34.verse: They showed the elephants the juice of grapes and mulberries to provoke them to fight.

35.verse: The beasts were distributed along the phalanxes, each elephant having assigned to it a thousand men in coats of mail, with bronze helmets, and five hundred picked cavalry.

36.verse: These anticipated the beast wherever it was; and wherever it moved, they moved too and never left it.

37.verse: A strong wooden tower covering each elephant, and fastened to it by a harness, held, besides the Indian mahout, three soldiers who fought from it.

38.verse: The remaining cavalry were stationed on one or the other of the two flanks of the army, to harass the enemy and to be protected from the phalanxes.

39.verse: When the sun shone on the gold and bronze shields, the mountains gleamed with their brightness and blazed like flaming torches.

40.verse: Part of the king's army extended over the heights, while some were on low ground, but they marched forward steadily and in good order.

41.verse: All who heard the noise of their numbers, the tramp of their marching, and the clashing of the arms, trembled; for the army was very great and strong.

42.verse: Judas with his army advanced to fight, and six hundred men of the king's army fell.

43.verse: Eleazar, called Avaran, saw one of the beasts bigger than any of the others and covered with royal armor, and he thought the king must be on it.

44.verse: So he gave up his life to save his people and win an everlasting name for himself.

45.verse: He dashed up to it in the middle of the phalanx, killing men right and left, so that they fell back from him on both sides.

46.verse: He ran right under the elephant and stabbed it in the belly, killing it. The beast fell to the ground on top of him, and he died there.

47.verse: When the Jews saw the strength of the royal army and the ardor of its forces, they retreated from them.

48.verse: A part of the king's army went up to Jerusalem to attack them, and the king established camps in Judea and at Mount Zion.

49.verse: He made peace with the men of Beth-zur, and they evacuated the city, because they had no food there to enable them to stand a siege, for that was a sabbath year in the land.

50.verse: The king took Beth-zur and stationed a garrison there to hold it.

51.verse: For many days he besieged the sanctuary, setting up artillery and machines, fire-throwers, catapults and mechanical bows for shooting arrows and slingstones.

52.verse: The Jews countered by setting up machines of their own, and kept up the fight a long time.

53.verse: But there were no provisions in the storerooms, because it was the seventh year, and the tide-over provisions had been eaten up by those who had been rescued from the Gentiles and brought to Judea.

54.verse: Few men remained in the sanctuary; the rest scattered, each to his own home, for the famine was too much for them.

55.verse: Lysias heard that Philip, whom King Antiochus, before his death, had appointed to train his son Antiochus to be king,

56.verse: had returned from Persia and Media with the army that accompanied the king, and that he was seeking to take over the government.

57.verse: So he hastily resolved to withdraw. He said to the king, the leaders of the army, and the soldiers: "We are grow-ing weaker every day, our provisions are scanty, the place we are besieging is strong, and it is our duty to take care of the affairs of the kingdom.

58.verse: Therefore let us now come to terms with these men, and make peace with them and all their nation.

59.verse: Let us grant them freedom to live according to their own laws as formerly; it was on account of their laws, which we abolished, that they became angry and did all these things."

60.verse: The proposal found favor with the king and the leaders;

61.verse: he sent peace terms to the Jews, and they accepted. So the king and the leaders swore an oath to them, and on these terms they evacuated the fortification.

62.verse: But when the king entered Mount Zion and saw how the place was fortified, he broke the oath he had sworn and gave orders for the encircling wall to be destroyed.

63.verse: Then he departed in haste and returned to Antioch, where he found Philip in possession of the city. He fought against him and took the city by force.

annotations.1: [1] Elymais: the mountainous region of Elam, north of the Persian Gulf. This section continues the story from 1 Macc 3:37 and pertains to events preceding those in 1 Macc 4:37-39.
annotations.2: [16] The year one hundred and forty-nine: September 22, 164, to October 9, 163 B.C. A Babylonian list of the Seleucid kings indicates that Antiochus died in November or early December of 164
annotations.3: [17] The king's son Antiochus: Antiochus V Eupator, then about nine years old. He was in Antioch, still in the charge of Lysias, who proceeded to govern and wage wars in his name. Both were put to death two years later, when Demetrius, brother of Antiochus IV, arrived to claim the kingship; cf 1 Macc 7:1-3
annotations.4: [20] The year one hundred and fifty: October, 163, to September, 162 B.C
annotations.5: [49] A sabbath year in the land: when sowing and reaping were prohibited ( Exodus 23:10-11; Lev 25:2-7). The year without a harvest (autumn of 164 to autumn of 163) was followed by a food shortage

1.verse: In the year one hundred and fifty-one, Demetrius, son of Seleucus, set out from Rome, arrived with a few men in a city on the seacoast, and began to rule there.

2.verse: As he was preparing to enter the royal palace of his ancestors, the soldiers seized Antiochus and Lysias to bring them to him.

3.verse: When he was informed of this, he said, "Do not show me their faces."

4.verse: So the soldiers killed them, and Demetrius sat on the royal throne.

5.verse: Then all the lawless and impious men of Israel came to him. They were led by Alcimus, who desired to be high priest.

6.verse: They made this accusation to the king against the people: "Judas and his brothers have destroyed all your friends and have driven us out of our country.

7.verse: So now, send a man whom you trust to go and see all the havoc Judas has done to us and to the king's land, and let him punish them and all their supporters."

8.verse: Then the king chose Bacchides, one of the King's Friends, governor of West-of-Euphrates, a great man in the kingdom, and faithful to the king.

9.verse: He sent him and the impious Alcimus, to whom he granted the high priesthood, with orders to take revenge on the Israelites.

10.verse: They set out and, on arriving in the land of Judah with a great army, sent messengers who spoke deceitfully to Judas and his brothers in peaceful terms.

11.verse: But these paid no attention to their words, seeing that they had come with a great army.

12.verse: A group of scribes, however, gathered about Alcimus and Bacchides to ask for a just agreement.

13.verse: The Hasideans were the first among the Israelites to seek peace with them,

14.verse: for they said, "A priest of the line of Aaron has come with the army, and he will not do us any wrong."

15.verse: He spoke with them peacefully and swore to them, "We will not try to injure you or your friends."

16.verse: So they trusted him. But he arrested sixty of them and killed them in one day, according to the text of Scripture:

17.verse: "The flesh of your saints they have strewn, and their blood they have shed round about Jerusalem, and there was no one to bury them."

18.verse: Then fear and dread of them came upon all the people, who said: "There is no truth or justice among them; they violated the agreement and the oath that they swore."

19.verse: Bacchides withdrew from Jerusalem and pitched his camp in Beth-zaith. He had many of the men arrested who deserted to him, throwing them into the great pit.

20.verse: He handed the province over to Alcimus, leaving troops to help him, while he himself returned to the king.

21.verse: Alcimus spared no pains to maintain his high priesthood,

22.verse: and all those who were disturbing their people gathered about him. They took possession of the land of Judah and caused great distress in Israel.

23.verse: When Judas saw all the evils that Alcimus and his men were bringing upon the Israelites, more than even the Gentiles had done,

24.verse: he went about all the borders of Judea and took revenge on the men who had deserted, preventing them from going out into the country.

25.verse: But when Alcimus saw that Judas and his followers were gaining strength and realized that he could not oppose them, he returned to the king and accused them of grave crimes.

26.verse: Then the king sent Nicanor, one of his famous officers, who was a bitter enemy of Israel, with orders to destroy the people.

27.verse: Nicanor came to Jerusalem with a large force and deceitfully sent to Judas and his brothers this peaceable message:

28.verse: "Let there be no fight between me and you. I will come with a few men to meet you peaceably."

29.verse: So he came to Judas, and they greeted one another peaceably. But Judas' enemies were prepared to seize him.

30.verse: When he became aware that Nicanor had come to him with treachery in mind, Judas was afraid and would not meet him again.

31.verse: When Nicanor saw that his plan had been discovered, he went out to fight Judas near Capharsalama.

32.verse: About five hundred men of Nicanor's army fell; the rest fled to the City of David.

33.verse: After this, Nicanor went up to Mount Zion. Some of the priests from the sanctuary and some of the elders of the people came out to greet him peaceably and to show him the holocaust that was being offered for the king.

34.verse: But he mocked and ridiculed them, defiled them, and spoke disdainfully.

35.verse: In a rage he swore: "If Judas and his army are not delivered to me at once, when I return victorious I will burn this temple down." He went away in great anger.

36.verse: The priests, however, went in and stood before the altar and the sanctuary. They wept and said:

37.verse: "You have chosen this house to bear your name, to be a house of prayer and petition for your people.

38.verse: Take revenge on this man and his army, and let them fall by the sword. Remember their blasphemies, and do not let them continue."

39.verse: Nicanor left Jerusalem and pitched his camp at Beth-horon, where the Syrian army joined him.

40.verse: But Judas camped in Adasa with three thousand men. Here Judas uttered this prayer:

41.verse: "When they who were sent by the king blasphemed, your angel went out and killed a hundred and eighty-five thousand of them.

42.verse: In the same way, crush this army before us today, and let the rest know that Nicanor spoke wickedly against your sanctuary; judge him according to his wickedness."

43.verse: The armies met in battle on the thirteenth day of the month Adar. Nicanor's army was crushed, and he himself was the first to fall in the battle.

44.verse: When his army saw that Nicanor was dead, they threw down their arms and fled.

45.verse: The Jews pursued them a day's journey, from Adasa to near Gazara, blowing the trumpets behind them as signals.

46.verse: From all the surrounding villages of Judea people came out and closed in on them. They hemmed them in, and all the enemies fell by the sword; not a single one escaped.

47.verse: Then the Jews collected the spoils and the booty; they cut off Nicanor's head and his right arm, which he had lifted up so arrogantly. These they brought to Jerusalem and displayed there.

48.verse: The people rejoiced greatly, and observed that day as a great festival.

49.verse: They decreed that it should be observed every year on the thirteenth of Adar.

50.verse: And for a short time the land of Judah was quiet.

annotations.1: [1-3] The year one hundred and fifty-one: the spring of 161 B.C. Demetrius, son of Seleucus, was the lawful heir to the kingdom; but when only nine years old, he was taken as a hostage at Rome in place of his uncle, who ruled as Antiochus IV Epiphanes. At the age of twenty-five Demetrius fled secretly from Rome and, with the support of the Syrians, overcame his rival Antiochus V and put him to death. The royal palace: at Antioch.
annotations.2: [5-6] Alcimus: a renegade Jew hostile to the Maccabees, who became high priest after the death of Menelaus ( 2 Macc 14:3). He received confirmation in his office from the new King Demetrius ( 2 Macc 7:9), and brought malicious charges against Judas and his brothers and the people ( 2 Macc 7:6). He wrought more evils on the Israelites than the Gentiles had done ( 2 Macc 8:23)
annotations.3: [19] Beth-zaith: about three miles north of Beth-zur and twelve miles south of Jerusalem
annotations.4: [27] Nicanor . . . deceitfully sent to Judas: a more favorable picture of Nicanor, as an honest man who became a personal friend of Judas, is given in 2 Macc 14:17-25. Their friendship was broken by the intrigues of Alcimus ( 2 Macc 14:26-30)
annotations.5: [31] Caphar-salama: a village seven miles north-northwest of Jerusalem, on the road leading to Beth-horon
annotations.6: Defiled them: spitting on the priests caused them to become legally defiled
annotations.7: [40] Adasa: a village southeast of Caphar-salama
annotations.8: [49] The thirteenth of Adar: March 27, 160 B.C. This day in the Jewish calendar was called the "Day of Nicanor" ( 2 Macc 15:36), but it was not long celebrated by the Jews
annotations.9: [50] A short time: about one month following the death of Nicanor. After that began the attack of Bacchides resulting in the death of Judas ( 1 Macc 9:1-18)

1.verse: After Alexander the Macedonian, Philip's son, who came from the land of Kittim, had defeated Darius, king of the Persians and Medes, he became king in his place, having first ruled in Greece.

2.verse: He fought many campaigns, captured fortresses, and put kings to death.

3.verse: He advanced to the ends of the earth, gathering plunder from many nations; the earth fell silent before him, and his heart became proud and arrogant.

4.verse: He collected a very strong army and conquered provinces, nations, and rulers, and they became his tributaries.

5.verse: But after all this he took to his bed, realizing that he was going to die.

6.verse: He therefore summoned his officers, the nobles, who had been brought up with him from his youth, to divide his kingdom among them while he was still alive.

7.verse: Alexander had reigned twelve years when he died.

8.verse: So his officers took over his kingdom, each in his own territory,

9.verse: and after his death they all put on royal crowns, and so did their sons after them for many years, causing much distress over the earth.

10.verse: There sprang from these a sinful offshoot, Antiochus Epiphanes, son of King Antiochus, once a hostage at Rome. He became king in the year one hundred and thirty-seven of the kingdom of the Greeks.

11.verse: In those days there appeared in Israel men who were breakers of the law, and they seduced many people, saying: "Let us go and make an alliance with the Gentiles all around us; since we separated from them, many evils have come upon us."

13.verse: some from among the people promptly went to the king, and he authorized them to introduce the way of living of the Gentiles.

14.verse: Thereupon they built a gymnasium in Jerusalem according to the Gentile custom.

15.verse: They covered over the mark of their circumcision and abandoned the holy covenant; they allied themselves with the Gentiles and sold themselves to wrongdoing.

16.verse: When his kingdom seemed secure, Antiochus proposed to become king of Egypt, so as to rule over both kingdoms.

17.verse: He invaded Egypt with a strong force, with chariots and elephants, and with a large fleet,

18.verse: to make war on Ptolemy, king of Egypt. Ptolemy was frightened at his presence and fled, leaving many casualties.

19.verse: The fortified cities in the land of Egypt were captured, and Antiochus plundered the land of Egypt.

20.verse: After Antiochus had defeated Egypt in the year one hundred and forty-three, he returned and went up to Israel and to Jerusalem with a strong force.

21.verse: He insolently invaded the sanctuary and took away the golden altar, the lampstand for the light with all its fixtures,

22.verse: the offering table, the cups and the bowls, the golden censers, the curtain, the crowns, and the golden ornament on the facade of the temple. He stripped off everything,

23.verse: and took away the gold and silver and the precious vessels; he also took all the hidden treasures he could find.

24.verse: Taking all this, he went back to his own country, after he had spoken with great arrogance and shed much blood.

25.verse: And there was great mourning for Israel, in every place where they dwelt,

26.verse: and the rulers and the elders groaned. Virgins and young men languished, and the beauty of the women was disfigured.

27.verse: Every bridegroom took up lamentation, she who sat in the bridal chamber mourned,

28.verse: And the land was shaken on account of its inhabitants, and all the house of Jacob was covered with shame.

29.verse: Two years later, the king sent the Mysian commander to the cities of Judah, and he came to Jerusalem with a strong force.

30.verse: He spoke to them deceitfully in peaceful terms, and won their trust. Then he attacked the city suddenly, in a great onslaught, and destroyed many of the people in Israel.

31.verse: He plundered the city and set fire to it, demolished its houses and its surrounding walls,

32.verse: took captive the women and children, and seized the cattle.

33.verse: Then they built up the City of David with a high, massive wall and strong towers, and it became their citadel.

34.verse: There they installed a sinful race, perverse men, who fortified themselves inside it,

35.verse: storing up weapons and provisions, and depositing there the plunder they had collected from Jerusalem. And they became a great threat.

36.verse: The citadel became an ambush against the sanctuary, and a wicked adversary to Israel at all times.

37.verse: And they shed innocent blood around the sanctuary; they defiled the sanctuary.

38.verse: Because of them the inhabitants of Jerusalem fled away, and she became the abode of strangers. She became a stranger to her own offspring, and her children forsook her.

39.verse: Her sanctuary was as desolate as a wilderness; her feasts were turned into mourning, Her sabbaths to shame, her honor to contempt.

40.verse: Her dishonor was as great as her glory had been, and her exalation was turned into mourning.

41.verse: Then the king wrote to his whole kingdom that all should be one people,

42.verse: each abandoning his particular customs. All the Gentiles conformed to the command of the king,

43.verse: and many Israelites were in favor of his religion; they sacrificed to idols and profaned the sabbath.

44.verse: The king sent messengers with letters to Jerusalem and to the cities of Judah, ordering them to follow customs foreign to their land;

45.verse: to prohibit holocausts, sacrifices, and libations in the sanctuary, to profane the sabbaths and feast days,

46.verse: to desecrate the sanctuary and the sacred ministers,

47.verse: to build pagan altars and temples and shrines, to sacrifice swine and unclean animals,

48.verse: to leave their sons uncircumcised, and to let themselves be defiled with every kind of impurity and abomination,

49.verse: so that they might forget the law and change all their observances.

50.verse: Whoever refused to act according to the command of the king should be put to death.

51.verse: Such were the orders he published throughout his kingdom. He appointed inspectors over all the people, and he ordered the cities of Judah to offer sacrifices, each city in turn.

52.verse: Many of the people, those who abandoned the law, joined them and committed evil in the land.

53.verse: Israel was driven into hiding, wherever places of refuge could be found.

54.verse: On the fifteenth day of the month Chislev, in the year one hundred and forty-five, the king erected the horrible abomination upon the altar of holocausts, and in the surrounding cities of Judah they built pagan altars.

55.verse: They also burnt incense at the doors of houses and in the streets.

56.verse: Any scrolls of the law which they found they tore up and burnt.

57.verse: Whoever was found with a scroll of the covenant, and whoever observed the law, was condemned to death by royal decree.

58.verse: So they used their power against Israel, against those who were caught, each month, in the cities.

59.verse: On the twenty-fifth day of each month they sacrificed on the altar erected over the altar of holocausts.

60.verse: Women who had had their children circumcised were put to death, in keeping with the decree,

61.verse: with the babies hung from their necks; their families also and those who had circumcised them were killed.

62.verse: But many in Israel were determined and resolved in their hearts not to eat anything unclean;

63.verse: they preferred to die rather than to be defiled with unclean food or to profane the holy covenant; and they did die. Terrible affliction was upon Israel.ä"...

annotations.1: [1] Land of Kittim: Greece. The name referred originally to inhabitants of Kiti, capital of the isle of Cyprus, then to any Cypriots ( Isaiah 23:1; Jeremiah 2:10), later to Greeks in general, and finally even to Romans. See note on Daniel 11:30. Darius: Darius III, Codoman (336-331 B.C.).
annotations.3: [10] The year one hundred and thirty-seven: Antiochus IV seized the throne in September, 175 B.C. Dates are given in this book according to the Seleucid era, which however was reckoned in two different ways. Antiochians considered this date to be October, 312 B.C. (Syrian calendar), while Babylonians and Jewish priests accepted April, 311 B.C. as the commencement of the era (temple calendar). The author of 1 Macc dates political events by the Syrian calendar but religious events by the temple calendar. Accordingly, the civil New Year occurred variously in September or October, the religious New Year in March or April
annotations.4: [14] Gymnasium: symbol and center of athletic and intellectual life, it was the chief instrument of Hellenistic propaganda. Jewish youth were attracted by sports and encouraged to join youth clubs. They received training in military skills and in the duties of citizens. Through participation in the intellectual life, many were gradually won over to paganism
annotations.5: [17] Elephants: an important part of Seleucid armament. About 300 B.C. Seleucus I, founder of the dynasty, procured five hundred of them from India; cf 1 Macc 6:34-37
annotations.6: [20] Defeated Egypt in the year one hundred and forty-three: 169 B.C. No mention is made in 1 Mc of the second expedition to Egypt a year later, described in 2 Macc 5:1, 11; Daniel 11:25, 19 records both
annotations.7: [33] City of David: not Mount Zion on the eastern hill of Jerusalem, which David captured from the Jebusites ( 2 Sam 5:7), but a new fortress built on the western hill and overlooking the temple and its courts on Mount Zion. It was occupied for twenty-six years by the Syro-Macedonian garrison, together with apostate Jews, and was a continual threat to the temple and the Jewish people ( 1 Macc 1:36); cf 1 Macc 13:49-51
annotations.8: [54] Fifteenth day of the month Chislev, in the year one hundred and forty-five: December 6, 167 B.C. Horrible abomination: in the original Hebrew, a contemptuous pun on the title "Lord of heaven" given to the god Zeus Olympios, to whom an image or perhaps an altar was erected upon the altar of holocausts in the temple of Jerusalem; cf Daniel 9:27; 11:31
annotations.9: [56-57] Scrolls of the law: one or more of the first five books of the Old Testament

1.verse: Then his son Judas, who was called Maccabeus, took his place.

2.verse: All his brothers and all who had joined his father supported him, and they carried on Israel's war joyfully.

3.verse: He spread abroad the glory of his people, and put on his breastplate like a giant. He armed himself with weapons of war; he planned battles and protected the camp with his sword.

4.verse: In his actions he was like a lion, like a young lion roaring for prey.

5.verse: He pursued the wicked, hunting them out, and those who troubled his people he destroyed by fire.

6.verse: The lawbreakers were cowed by fear of him, and all evildoers were dismayed. By his hand redemption was happily achieved,

7.verse: and he afflicted many kings; He made Jacob glad by his deeds, and his memory is blessed forever.

8.verse: He went about the cities of Judah destroying the impious there. He turned away wrath from Israel

9.verse: and was renowned to the ends of the earth; he gathered together those who were perishing.

10.verse: Then Apollonius gathered the Gentiles, together with a large army from Samaria, to fight against Israel.

11.verse: When Judas learned of it, he went out to meet him and defeated and killed him. Many fell wounded, and the rest fled.

12.verse: Their possessions were seized and the sword of Apollonius was taken by Judas, who fought with it the rest of his life.

13.verse: But Seron, commander of the Syrian army, heard that Judas had gathered many about him, an assembly of faithful men ready for war.

14.verse: So he said, "I will make a name for myself and win glory in the kingdom by defeating Judas and his followers, who have despised the king's command."

15.verse: And again a large company of renegades advanced with him to help him take revenge on the Israelites.

16.verse: When he reached the ascent of Beth-horon, Judas went out to meet him with a few men.

17.verse: But when they saw the army coming against them, they said to Judas: "How can we, few as we are, fight such a mighty host as this? Besides, we are weak today from fasting."

18.verse: But Judas said: "It is easy for many to be overcome by a few; in the sight of Heaven there is no difference between deliverance by many or by few;

19.verse: for victory in war does not depend upon the size of the army, but on strength that comes from Heaven.

20.verse: With great presumption and lawlessness they come against us to destroy us and our wives and children and to despoil us;

21.verse: but we are fighting for our lives and our laws.

22.verse: He himself will crush them before us; so do not be afraid of them."

23.verse: When he finished speaking, he rushed suddenly upon Seron and his army, who were crushed before him.

24.verse: He pursued Seron down the descent of Beth-horon into the plain. About eight hundred of their men fell, and the rest fled to the country of the Philistines.

25.verse: Then Judas and his brothers began to be feared, and dread fell upon the Gentiles about them.

26.verse: His fame reached the king, and all the Gentiles talked about the battles of Judas.

27.verse: When Antiochus heard about these events, he was angry; so he ordered a muster of all the forces of his kingdom, a very strong army.

28.verse: He opened his treasure chests, gave his soldiers a year's pay, and commanded them to be prepared for anything.

29.verse: He then found that this exhausted the money in his treasury; moreover the income from the province was small, because of the dissension and distress he had brought upon the land by abolishing the laws which had been in effect from of old.

30.verse: He feared that, as had happened more than once, he would not have enough for his expenses and for the gifts that he had previously given with a more liberal hand than the preceding kings.

31.verse: Greatly perplexed, he decided to go to Persia and levy tribute on those provinces, and so raise a large sum of money.

32.verse: He left Lysias, a nobleman of royal blood, in charge of the king's affairs from the Euphrates River to the frontier of Egypt,

33.verse: and commissioned him to take care of his son Antiochus until his own return.

34.verse: He entrusted to him half of the army, and the elephants, and gave him instructions concerning everything he wanted done. As for the inhabitants of Judea and Jerusalem,

35.verse: Lysias was to send an army against them to crush and destroy the power of Israel and the remnant of Jerusalem and efface their memory from the land.

36.verse: He was to settle foreigners in all their territory and distribute their land by lot.

37.verse: The king took the remaining half of the army and set out from Antioch, his capital, in the year one hundred and forty-seven; he crossed the Euphrates River and advanced inland.

38.verse: Lysias chose Ptolemy, son of Dorymenes, and Nicanor and Gorgias, capable men among the King's Friends,

39.verse: and with them he sent forty thousand men and seven thousand cavalry to invade the land of Judah and ravage it according to the king's orders.

40.verse: Setting out with all their forces, they came and pitched their camp near Emmaus in the plain.

41.verse: When the merchants of the country heard of their fame, they came to the camp, bringing fetters and a large sum of silver and gold, to buy the Israelites as slaves. A force from Idumea and from Philistia joined with them.

42.verse: Judas and his brothers saw that the situation had become critical now that armies were encamped within their territory; they knew of the orders which the king had given to destroy and utterly wipe out the people.

43.verse: So they said to one another, "Let us restore our people from their ruined estate, and fight for our people and our sanctuary!"

44.verse: The assembly gathered together to prepare for battle and to pray and implore mercy and compassion.

45.verse: Jerusalem was uninhabited, like a desert; not one of her children entered or came out. The sanctuary was trampled on, and foreigners were in the citadel; it was a habitation of Gentiles. Joy had disappeared from Jacob, and the flute and the harp were silent.

46.verse: Thus they assembled and went to Mizpah near Jerusalem, because there was formerly at Mizpah a place of prayer for Israel.

47.verse: That day they fasted and wore sackcloth; they sprinkled ashes on their heads and tore their clothes.

48.verse: They unrolled the scroll of the law, to learn about the things for which the Gentiles consulted the images of their idols.

49.verse: They brought with them the priestly vestments, the first fruits, and the tithes; and they brought forward the nazirites who had completed the time of their vows.

50.verse: And they cried aloud to Heaven: "What shall we do with these men, and where shall we take them?

51.verse: For your sanctuary has been trampled on and profaned, and your priests are in mourning and humiliation.

52.verse: Now the Gentiles are gathered together against us to destroy us. You know what they plot against us.

53.verse: How shall we be able to resist them unless you help us?"

54.verse: Then they blew the trumpets and cried out loudly.

55.verse: After this Judas appointed officers among the people, over thousands, over hundreds, over fifties, and over tens.

56.verse: He proclaimed that those who were building houses, or were just married, or were planting vineyards, and those who were afraid, could each return to his home, according to the law.

57.verse: Then the army moved off, and they camped to the south of Emmaus.

58.verse: Judas said: "Arm yourselves and be brave; in the morning be ready to fight these Gentiles who have assembled against us to destroy us and our sanctuary.

59.verse: It is better for us to die in battle than to witness the ruin of our nation and our sanctuary. Whatever Heaven wills, he will do."

annotations.1: [10] Apollonius: the Mysian commander mentioned in 1 Macc 1:29; 2 Macc 5:24.
annotations.2: [16] Beth-horon: the famous pass leading up from the coastal plain to the Judean hill country. Here Joshua won an important battle ( Joshua 10:10-11), and in 66 A.D. a Roman force under Cestius was trapped and massacred
annotations.3: [22] He himself: out of reverence for God, the author of 1 Macc prefers to use this and other expressions, such as "Heaven," instead of the divine name. Cf 1 Macc 3:50
annotations.4: [24] About eight hundred: the figures given in this book for strength of armies and number of casualties are not to be taken literally. In accordance with biblical usage, they indicate rather the importance of the battle described or the greatness of the victory
annotations.5: [37] This expedition, in the spring of 165 B.C., resulted in failure; cf 1 Macc 6
annotations.6: [38] Nicanor: the leader of another attack against the Jews four years later. He was finally killed by Judas; cf 1 Macc 7:26-46
annotations.7: [40] Emmaus: probably not the village mentioned in Luke 24:13 but a settlement about twenty miles west of Jerusalem at the edge of the hill country
annotations.8: [46] ...Mizpah a place of prayer for Israel: a holy place established of old eight miles north and slightly west of Jerusalem. It was here that Samuel began to judge the Israelites ( 1 Sam 7:5-11; 10:17)
annotations.9: [48] To learn . . . idols: favorable omens for the coming battle. A contrast is intended between the idol worship of the pagans and the consultation of the word of God by the Jews; cf 2 Macc 8:23

1.verse: In the year one hundred and sixty, Alexander, who was called Epiphanes, son of Antiochus, came up and took Ptolemais. He was accepted and began to reign there.

2.verse: When King Demetrius heard of it, he mustered a very large army and marched out to engage him in combat.

3.verse: Demetrius sent a letter to Jonathan written in peaceful terms, to pay him honor;

4.verse: for he said: "Let us be the first to make peace with him, before he makes peace with Alexander against us,

5.verse: since he will remember all the wrongs we have done to him, his brothers, and his nation."

6.verse: So Demetrius authorized him to gather an army and procure arms as his ally; and he ordered that the hostages in the citadel be released to him.

7.verse: Accordingly Jonathan went up to Jerusalem and read the letter to all the people. The men in the citadel

8.verse: were struck with fear when they heard that the king had given him authority to gather an army.

9.verse: They released the hostages to Jonathan, and he gave them back to their parents.

10.verse: Thereafter Jonathan dwelt in Jerusalem, and began to build and restore the city.

11.verse: He ordered the workmen to build the walls and encircle Mount Zion with square stones for its fortification, which they did.

12.verse: The foreigners in the strongholds that Bacchides had built, took flight;

13.verse: each one of them left his place and returned to his own country.

14.verse: Only in Beth-zur did some remain of those who had abandoned the law and the commandments, for they used it as a place of refuge.

15.verse: King Alexander heard of the promises that Demetrius had made to Jonathan; he was also told of the battles and valiant deeds of Jonathan and his brothers and the troubles that they had endured.

16.verse: He said, "Shall we ever find another man like him? Let us now make him our friend and ally."

17.verse: So he sent Jonathan a letter written in these terms:

18.verse: "King Alexander sends greetings to his brother Jonathan.

19.verse: We have heard of you, that you are a mighty warrior and worthy to be our friend.

20.verse: We have therefore appointed you today to be high priest of your nation; you are to be called the King's Friend, and you are to look after our interests and preserve amity with us." He also sent him a purple robe and a crown of gold.

21.verse: Jonathan put on the sacred vestments in the seventh month of the year one hundred and sixty at the feast of Booths, and he gathered an army and procured many arms.

22.verse: When Demetrius heard of these things, he was distressed and said:

23.verse: "Why have we allowed Alexander to get ahead of us by gaining the friendship of the Jews and thus strengthening himself?

24.verse: I too will write them conciliatory words and offer dignities and gifts, so that they may be an aid to me."

25.verse: So he sent them this message: "King Demetrius sends greetings to the Jewish nation.

26.verse: We have heard how you have kept the treaty with us and continued in our friendship and not gone over to our enemies, and we are glad.

27.verse: Continue, therefore, to keep faith with us, and we will reward you with favors in return for what you do in our behalf.

28.verse: We will grant you many exemptions and will bestow gifts on you.

29.verse: "I now free you, as I also exempt all the Jews, from the tribute, the salt tax, and the crown levies.

30.verse: Instead of collecting the third of the grain and the half of the fruit of the trees that should be my share, I renounce the right from this day forward: Neither now nor in the future will I collect them from the land of Judah or from the three districts annexed from Samaria.

31.verse: Let Jerusalem and her territory, her tithes and her tolls, be sacred and free from tax.

32.verse: I also yield my authority over the citadel in Jerusalem, and I transfer it to the high priest, that he may put in it such men as he shall choose to guard it.

33.verse: Every one of the Jews who has been carried into captivity from the land of Judah into any part of my kingdom I set at liberty without ransom; and let all their taxes, even those on their cattle, be canceled.

34.verse: Let all feast days, sabbaths, new moon festivals, appointed days, and the three days that precede each feast day, and the three days that follow, be days of immunity and exemption for every Jew in my kingdom.

35.verse: Let no man have authority to exact payment from them or to molest any of them in any matter.

36.verse: "Let thirty thousand Jews be enrolled in the king's army and allowances be given them, as is due to all the king's soldiers.

37.verse: Let some of them be stationed in the king's principal strongholds, and of these let some be given positions of trust in the affairs of the kingdom. Let their superiors and their rulers be taken from among them, and let them follow their own laws, as the king has commanded in the land of Judah.

38.verse: "Let the three districts that have been added to Judea from the province of Samaria be incorporated with Judea so that they may be under one man and obey no other authority than the high priest.

39.verse: Ptolemais and its confines I give as a present to the sanctuary in Jerusalem for the necessary expenses of the sanctuary.

40.verse: I make a yearly personal grant of fifteen thousand silver shekels out of the royal revenues, from appropriate places.

41.verse: All the additional funds that the officials did not hand over as they had done in the first years, shall henceforth be handed over for the services of the temple.

42.verse: Moreover, the dues of five thousand silver shekels that used to be taken from the revenue of the sanctuary every year shall be canceled, since these funds belong to the priests who perform the services.

43.verse: Whoever takes refuge in the temple of Jerusalem or in any of its precincts, because of money he owes the king, or because of any other debt, shall be released, together with all the goods he possesses in my kingdom. \

44.verse: The cost of rebuilding and restoring the structures of the sanctuary shall be covered out of the royal revenue.

45.verse: Likewise the cost of building the walls of Jerusalem and fortifying it all around, and of building walls in Judea, shall be donated from the royal revenue."

46.verse: When Jonathan and the people heard these words, they neither believed nor accepted them, for they remembered the great evil that Demetrius had done in Israel, and how sorely he had afflicted them.

47.verse: They therefore decided in favor of Alexander, for he had been the first to address them peaceably, and they remained his allies for the rest of his life.

48.verse: King Alexander gathered together a large army and encamped opposite Demetrius.

49.verse: The two kings joined battle, and when the army of Demetrius fled, Alexander pursued him, and overpowered his soldiers.

50.verse: He pressed the battle hard until sunset, and Demetrius fell that day.

51.verse: Alexander sent ambassadors to Ptolemy, king of Egypt, with this message:

52.verse: "Now that I have returned to my realm, taken my seat on the throne of my fathers, and established my rule by crushing Demetrius and gaining control of my country -

53.verse: for I engaged him in battle, defeated him and his army, and recovered the royal throne -

54.verse: let us now establish friendship with each other. Give me your daughter for my wife; and as your son-in-law, I will give to you and to her gifts worthy of you."

55.verse: King Ptolemy answered in these words: "Happy the day on which you returned to the land of your fathers and took your seat on their royal throne!

56.verse: I will do for you what you have written; but meet me in Ptolemais, so that we may see each other, and I will become your father-in-law as you have proposed."

57.verse: So Ptolemy with his daughter Cleopatra set out from Egypt and came to Ptolemais in the year one hundred and sixty-two.

58.verse: There King Alexander met him, and Ptolemy gave him his daughter Cleopatra in marriage. Their wedding was celebrated at Ptolemais with great splendor according to the custom of kings.

59.verse: King Alexander also wrote to Jonathan to come and meet him.

60.verse: So he went with pomp to Ptolemais, where he met the two kings and gave them and their friends silver and gold and many gifts and thus won their favor.

61.verse: Some pestilent Israelites, transgressors of the law, united against him to accuse him, but the king paid no heed to them.

62.verse: He ordered Jonathan to be divested of his ordinary garments and to be clothed in royal purple; and so it was done.

63.verse: The king also had him seated at his side. He said to his magistrates: "Go with him to the center of the city and make a proclamation that no one is to bring charges against him on any grounds or be troublesome to him in any way."

64.verse: When his accusers saw the honor paid to him in the proclamation, and the purple with which he was clothed, they all fled.

65.verse: The king also honored him by numbering him among his Chief Friends and made him military commander and governor of the province.

66.verse: So Jonathan returned in peace and happiness to Jerusalem.

67.verse: In the year one hundred and sixty-five, Demetrius, son of Demetrius, came from Crete to the land of his fathers.

68.verse: When King Alexander heard of it he was greatly troubled, and returned to Antioch.

69.verse: Demetrius appointed Apollonius governor of Coelesyria. Having gathered a large army, Appollonius pitched his camp at Jamnia. From there he sent this message to Jonathan the high priest:

70.verse: "You are the only one who resists us. I am laughed at and put to shame on your account. Why are you displaying power against us in the mountains?

71.verse: If you have confidence in your forces, come down now to us in the plain, and let us test each other's strength there; the city forces are on my side.

72.verse: Inquire and learn who I am and who the others are who are helping me. Men say that you cannot make a stand against us because your fathers were twice put to flight in their own land.

73.verse: Now you too will be unable to withstand our cavalry and such a force as this in the plain, where there is not a stone or a pebble or a place to flee."

74.verse: When Jonathan heard the message of Apollonius, he was roused. Choosing ten thousand men, he set out from Jerusalem, and Simon his brother joined him to help him.

75.verse: He pitched camp near Joppa, but the men in the city shut him out because Apollonius had a garrison there. When the Jews besieged it,

76.verse: the men of the city became afraid and opened the gates, and so Jonathan took possession of Joppa.

77.verse: When Apollonius heard of it, he drew up three thousand horsemen and an innumerable infantry. He marched on Azotus as though he were going on through the country, but at the same time he advanced into the plain, because he had such a large number of horsemen to rely on.

78.verse: Jonathan followed him to Azotus, and they engaged in battle.

79.verse: Apollonius, however, had left a thousand cavalry in hiding behind them.

80.verse: When Jonathan discovered that there was an ambush behind him, his army was surrounded. From morning until evening they showered his men with arrows.

81.verse: But his men held their ground, as Jonathan had commanded, whereas the enemy's horses became tired out.

82.verse: When the horsemen were exhausted, Simon attacked the phalanx, overwhelmed it and put it to flight.

83.verse: The horsemen too were scattered over the plain. The enemy fled to Azotus and entered Beth-dagon, the temple of their idol, to save themselves.

84.verse: But Jonathan burned and plundered Azotus with its neighboring towns, and destroyed by fire both the temple of Dagon and the men who had taken refuge in it.

85.verse: Those who fell by the sword, together with those who were burned alive, came to about eight thousand men.

86.verse: Then Jonathan left there and pitched his camp at Ashkalon, and the people of that city came out to meet him with great pomp.

87.verse: He and his men then returned to Jerusalem, laden with much booty.

88.verse: When King Alexander heard of these events, he accorded new honors to Jonathan.

89.verse: He sent him a gold buckle, such as is usually given to King's Kinsmen; he also gave him Ekron and all its territory as a possession.

annotations.1: [1] The year one hundred and sixty: 152 B.C. Alexander . . . Antiochus: Alexander Balas claimed to be a son of Antiochus IV. He had the backing of the Romans, who had never forgiven Demetrius for becoming king without their permission. The latter meanwhile had become unpopular with his own people as well as with the Jews.
annotations.2: [21] Jonathan . . . feast of Booths: Jonathan began to discharge the office of high priest October 23-30, 152 B.C. For seven years after the death of Alcimus there had been no high priest in Jerusalem. It was taken for granted that the king, though a Gentile, had the power to appoint one. The Maccabees, though a priestly family, were not of the line of Zadok, and some in Israel regarded Jonathan's tenure as a usurpation
annotations.3: [30] The three districts annexed from Samaria: mentioned by name in 1 Maccc 11;34. The present Greek text, by a scribal error, has added "and Galilee" after "Samaria."
annotations.4: [57] Cleopatra: Cleopatra Thea, then about fifteen years old. She later married Demetrius II, and later still, his brother Antiochus VII. The year one hundred and sixty-two: 151/150 B.C
annotations.5: [67] The year one hundred and sixty-five: 147 B.C. Demetrius: Demetrius II Nicator
annotations.6: [76] Joppa: about forty miles northwest of Jerusalem. For the first time the Maccabees took possession of a seaport; nominally it was on behalf of King Alexander
annotations.7: [89] Kinsmen: a class higher than Chief Friends

1.verse: Now Gorgias took five thousand infantry and a thousand picked cavalry, and this detachment set out at night

2.verse: in order to attack the camp of the Jews and take them by surprise. Some men from the citadel were their guides.

3.verse: Judas heard of it, and himself set out with his soldiers to attack the king's army at Emmaus,

4.verse: while the latter's forces were still scattered away from the camp.

5.verse: During the night Gorgias came into the camp of Judas, and found no one there; so he began to hunt for them in the mountains, saying, "They are fleeing from us."

6.verse: But at daybreak Judas appeared in the plain with three thousand men, who lacked such armor and swords as they would have wished.

7.verse: They saw the army of the Gentiles, strong and breastplated, flanked with cavalry, and made up of expert soldiers.

8.verse: Judas said to the men with him: "Do not be afraid of their numbers or dread their attack.

9.verse: Remember how our fathers were saved in the Red Sea, when Pharaoh pursued them with an army.

10.verse: So now let us cry to Heaven in the hope that he will favor us, remember his covenant with our fathers, and destroy this army before us today.

11.verse: All the Gentiles shall know that there is One who redeems and delivers Israel."

12.verse: When the foreigners looked up and saw them marching toward them,

13.verse: they came out of their camp for battle, and the men with Judas blew the trumpet.

14.verse: The battle was joined and the Gentiles were defeated and fled toward the plain.

15.verse: Their whole rearguard fell by the sword, and they were pursued as far as Gazara and the plains of Judea, to Azotus and Jamnia. About three thousand of their men fell.

16.verse: When Judas and the army returned from the pursuit,

17.verse: he said to the people: "Do not be greedy for the plunder, for there is a fight ahead of us,

18.verse: and Gorgias and his army are near us on the mountain. But now stand firm against our enemies and overthrow them. Afterward you can freely take the plunder."

19.verse: As Judas was finishing this speech, a detachment appeared, looking down from the mountain.

20.verse: They saw that their army had been put to flight and their camp was being burned. The smoke that could be seen indicated what had happened.

21.verse: When they realized this, they were terrified; and when they also saw the army of Judas in the plain ready to attack,

22.verse: they all fled to Philistine territory.

23.verse: Then Judas went back to plunder the camp, and his men collected much gold and silver, violet and crimson cloth, and great treasure.

24.verse: As they returned, they were singing hymns and glorifying Heaven, "for he is good, for his mercy endures forever."

25.verse: Thus Israel had a great deliverance that day.

26.verse: But those of the foreigners who had escaped went and told Lysias all that had occurred.

27.verse: When he heard it he was disturbed and discouraged, because things in Israel had not turned out as he intended and as the king had ordered.

28.verse: So the following year he gathered together sixty thousand picked men and five thousand cavalry, to subdue them.

29.verse: They came into Idumea and camped at Beth-zur, and Judas met them with ten thousand men.

30.verse: Seeing that the army was strong, he prayed thus: "Blessed are you, O Savior of Israel, who broke the rush of the mighty one by the hand of your servant David and delivered the camp of the Philistines into the hand of Jonathan, the son of Saul, and his armor-bearer.

31.verse: Give this army into the hands of your people Israel; make them ashamed of their troops and their cavalry.

32.verse: Strike them with fear, weaken the boldness of their strength, and let them tremble at their own destruction.

33.verse: Strike them down by the sword of those who love you, that all who know your name may hymn your praise."

34.verse: Then they engaged in battle, and about five thousand of Lysias' men fell in hand-to-hand fighting.

35.verse: When Lysias saw his ranks beginning to give way, and the increased boldness of Judas, whose men were ready either to live or to die bravely, he withdrew to Antioch and began to recruit mercenaries so as to return to Judea with greater numbers.

36.verse: Then Judas and his brothers said, "Now that our enemies have been crushed, let us go up to purify the sanctuary and rededicate it."

37.verse: So the whole army assembled, and went up to Mount Zion.

38.verse: They found the sanctuary desolate, the altar desecrated, the gates burnt, weeds growing in the courts as in a forest or on some mountain, and the priests' chambers demolished.

39.verse: Then they tore their clothes and made great lamentation; they sprinkled their heads with ashes

40.verse: and fell with their faces to the ground. And when the signal was given with trumpets, they cried out to Heaven.

41.verse: Judas appointed men to attack those in the citadel, while he purified the sanctuary.

42.verse: He chose blameless priests, devoted to the law;

43.verse: these purified the sanctuary and carried away the stones of the Abomination to an unclean place.

44.verse: They deliberated what ought to be done with the altar of holocausts that had been desecrated.

45.verse: The happy thought came to them to tear it down, lest it be a lasting shame to them that the Gentiles had defiled it; so they tore down the altar.

46.verse: They stored the stones in a suitable place on the temple hill, until a prophet should come and decide what to do with them.

47.verse: Then they took uncut stones, according to the law, and built a new altar like the former one.

48.verse: They also repaired the sanctuary and the interior of the temple and purified the courts.

49.verse: They made new sacred vessels and brought the lampstand, the altar of incense, and the table into the temple.

50.verse: Then they burned incense on the altar and lighted the lamps on the lampstand, and these illuminated the temple.

51.verse: They also put loaves on the table and hung up curtains. Thus they finished all the work they had undertaken.

52.verse: Early in the morning on the twenty-fifth day of the ninth month, that is, the month of Chislev, in the year one hundred and forty-eight,

53.verse: they arose and offered sacrifice according to the law on the new altar of holocausts that they had made.

54.verse: On the anniversary of the day on which the Gentiles had defiled it, on that very day it was reconsecrated with songs, harps, flutes, and cymbals.

55.verse: All the people prostrated themselves and adored and praised Heaven, who had given them success.

56.verse: For eight days they celebrated the dedication of the altar and joyfully offered holocausts and sacrifices of deliverance and praise.

57.verse: They ornamented the facade of the temple with gold crowns and shields; they repaired the gates and the priests' chambers and furnished them with doors.

58.verse: There was great joy among the people now that the disgrace of the Gentiles was removed.

59.verse: Then Judas and his brothers and the entire congregation of Israel decreed that the days of the dedication of the altar should be observed with joy and gladness on the anniversary every year for eight days, from the twenty-fifth day of the month Chislev.

60.verse: At that time they built high walls and strong towers around Mount Zion, to prevent the Gentiles from coming and trampling over it as they had done before.

61.verse: Judas also placed a garrison there to protect it, and likewise fortified Beth-zur, that the people might have a stronghold facing Idumea.
